Misappropriating, or failing to properly and promptly remit, funds received from clients for payment of taxes or other obligations due the United States. Directly or indirectly attempting to influence the official action of IRS employees by the use of threats, false accusations, duress, or coercion, or by offering gifts, favors, or any special inducements. Being disbarred or suspended from practice as an attorney, CPA, public accountant, or actuary, by the District of Columbia or any U.S. state, possession, territory, commonwealth, or any federal court, or any federal agency, body, or board. Knowingly aiding and abetting another person to practice before the IRS during a period of suspension, disbarment, or ineligibility of that other person. Using abusive language, making false accusations or statements knowing them to be false, circulating or publishing malicious or libelous matter, or engaging in any contemptuous conduct in connection with practice before the IRS. Giving a false opinion knowingly, recklessly, or through gross incompetence; or engaging in a pattern of providing incompetent opinions on questions arising under the federal tax laws.

The Secretary of the Treasury, or delegate, after notice and an opportunity for a proceeding, may censure, suspend, or disbar an individual subject to Circular 230 from practice before the IRS if the individual is shown to be incompetent or disreputable, fails to comply with the regulations in Subpart B; or with intent to defraud, willfully and knowingly misleads or threatens a client or prospective client. Censure is a public reprimand. Individuals subject to Circular 230 include any attorney, certified public accountant, enrolled agent, enrolled retirement plan agent, or enrolled actuary engaged in taxpayer representation or advice-giving activity, as well as any Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion holder who represents taxpayers and any appraiser engaged in appraising asset values for federal tax purposes.

A power of attorney is your written authorization for an individual to receive your confidential tax information from the IRS and to perform certain actions on your behalf. If the authorization is not limited, the individual generally can perform all acts that you can perform, except negotiating or endorsing a check. The authority granted to enrolled retirement plan agents, enrolled actuaries and unenrolled return preparers holding records of completion is limited. For information on the limits regarding annual filing season program record of completion holders, see Revenue Procedure 2014-42 and IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Return-Preparer-Office-RPO-At-a-Glance.

Attorneys, certified public accountants, and enrolled agents may perform the following acts: 1. Represent you before any office or employee of the IRS. 2. Sign an offer or a waiver of restriction on assessment or collection of a tax deficiency, or a waiver of notice of disallowance of claim for credit or refund. 3. Sign a consent to extend the statutory time period for assessment or collection of a tax. 4. Sign a closing agreement.

A recognized representative can substitute or delegate authority under the power of attorney to another recognized representative only if the act is specifically authorized by you on the power of attorney. After a substitution has been made, only the newly recognized representative will be recognized as the taxpayer's representative. If a delegation of power has been made, both the original and the delegated representative will be recognized by the IRS to represent you.

You also must attach to the non-IRS power of attorney a signed and dated statement made by your representative. This statement, which is referred to as the Declaration of Representative, is contained in Part II of Form 2848. The statement should read: 1. I am not currently under suspension or disbarment from practice before the Internal Revenue Service or other practice of my profession by any other authority, 2. I am subject to regulations contained in Circular 230 (31 C.F.R., Subtitle A, Part 10) as amended, governing practice before the Internal Revenue Service, 3. I am authorized to represent the taxpayer(s) identified in the power of attorney, and 4. I am a (naming the capacity in which representation is undertaken, as set forth in the list of eligible representatives at Part II of Form 2848.)

The IRS will not accept your non-IRS power of attorney if it does not contain all the information listed above. You can sign and submit a completed Form 2848 or a new non-IRS power of attorney that contains all the information. If you cannot sign an acceptable replacement document, your attorney-in-fact may be able to perfect (make acceptable to the IRS) your non-IRS power of attorney by using the procedure described next.

Under the following conditions, the attorney-in-fact named in your non-IRS power of attorney can sign a Form 2848 on your behalf. 1. The original non-IRS power of attorney grants authority to handle federal tax matters (for example, general authority to perform any acts). 2. The attorney-in-fact attaches a statement (signed under penalty of perjury) to the Form 2848 stating that the original non-IRS power of attorney is valid under the laws of the governing jurisdiction.

The IRS has a centralized computer database system called the CAF system. This system contains information on the authority of taxpayer representatives. Generally, when you submit a power of attorney document to the IRS, it is processed for inclusion on the CAF system. Entry of your power of attorney on the CAF system enables IRS personnel, who do not have a copy of your power of attorney, to verify the authority of your representative by accessing the CAF. It also enables the IRS to automatically send copies of notices and other IRS communications to your representative if you specify that your representative should receive those communications. You can have your non-IRS power of attorney entered on the CAF system by attaching it to a completed Form 2848 and submitting it to the IRS. Your signature is not required; however, your attorney-in-fact must sign the Declaration of Representative(see Part II of Form 2848).

Generally, you can mail or fax a paper Form 2848 directly to the IRS. To determine where you should file Form 2848, see Where To File in the Instructions for Form 2848. If Form 2848 is for a specific use, mail or fax it to the office handling that matter. For more information on specific use, see Line 4. Specific Use Not Recorded on CAF in the Instructions for Form 2848.

The IRS will accept a copy of a power of attorney that is submitted by facsimile transmission (fax). If you choose to file a power of attorney by fax, be sure the appropriate IRS office is equipped to accept this type of transmission. !This is an Image: taxtip.gif Your representative may be able to file Form 2848 electronically via the IRS website. For more information, your representative can go to IRS.gov/eServices. If you complete Form 2848 for electronic signature authorization, do not file Form 2848 with the IRS. Instead, give it to your representative, who will retain the document.

Submit any update or modification to an existing power of attorney in writing. Your signature (or the signature of the individual(s) authorized to sign on your behalf) is required. Do this by sending the updated Form 2848 or non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS office(s) where you previously sent the original(s), including the service center where the related return was, or will be filed. A recognized representative may substitute or delegate authority if you specifically authorize your representative to substitute or delegate representation in the original power of attorney. To make a substitution or delegation, the representative must file the following items with the IRS office(s) where the power of attorney was filed. 1. A written notice of substitution or delegation signed by the recognized representative. 2. A written declaration of representative made by the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney that specifically authorizes the substitution or delegation.

A newly filed power of attorney concerning the same matter will revoke a previously filed power of attorney. However, the new power of attorney will not revoke the prior power of attorney if it specifically states it does not revoke such prior power of attorney and either of the following are attached to the new power of attorney. A copy of the unrevoked prior power of attorney, or A statement signed by the taxpayer listing the name and address of each representative authorized under the prior unrevoked power of attorney.

If you want to revoke a previously executed power of attorney and do not want to name a new representative, you must write “REVOKE” across the top of the first page of the Form 2848 with a current signature and date immediately below this annotation. Then, you must mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the revocation annotation to the IRS, using the Where To File Chart in the Instructions for Form 2848, or if the power of attorney is for a specific matter, to the IRS office handling the matter. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney you want to revoke, you must send the IRS a statement of revocation that indicates the authority of the power of attorney is revoked, lists the matters and years/periods, and lists the name and address of each recognized representative whose authority is revoked. You must sign and date this statement. If you are completely revoking authority, write "remove all years/periods" instead of listing the specific matters and years/periods.

If your representative wants to withdraw from representation, he or she must write “WITHDRAW” across the top of the first page of the Form 2848 with a current signature and date immediately below the annotation. Then, he or she must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the withdrawal annotation to the IRS in the same manner described in Revocation by taxpayer above. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney he or she wants to withdraw, he or she must send the IRS a statement of withdrawal that indicates the authority of the power of attorney is withdrawn, lists the matters and years/periods, and lists the name, TIN, and address (if known) of the taxpayer. The representative must sign and date this statement. A power of attorney held by a student will be recorded on the CAF system for 130 days from the receipt date. If you are authorizing a student to represent you after that time, you will need to submit another updated Form 2848.

!This is an Image: caution.gif For partnership tax years beginning after December 31, 2017, the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015, which repealed the TEFRA partnership audit and litigation procedures and the rules applicable to electing large partnerships and replaced them with a new centralized partnership audit regime, has eliminated the role of “tax matters partner” and replaced it with “partnership representative.” Pursuant to Treasury Regulation section 301.9100-22T, certain partnerships can elect to have the new regime apply to partnership returns for tax years beginning after November 2, 2015, and before January 1, 2018.

If the power of attorney is complete and valid, the IRS will take action to recognize the representative. In most instances, this includes processing the document on the CAF system. Recording the data on the CAF system enables the IRS to direct copies of mailings to authorized representatives and to readily recognize the scope of authority granted.

The IRS uses the latest encryption technology to ensure your electronic payments are safe and secure. You can make electronic payments online, by phone, and from a mobile device using the IRS2Go app. Paying electronically is quick, easy, and faster than mailing in a check or money order. Go to IRS.gov/Payments to make a payment using any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your individual tax bill or estimated tax payment directly from your checking or savings account at no cost to you. Debit or credit card: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online, by phone, and by mobile device. Electronic Funds Withdrawal: Offered only when filing your federal taxes using tax preparation software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Best option for businesses. Enrollment is required. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on the notice or instructions. Cash: You may be able to pay your taxes with cash at a participating retail store.

The Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers and protects taxpayer rights. Our job is to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.

The Taxpayer Bill of Rights describes 10 basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. Our Tax Toolkit at TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov can help you understand what these rights mean to you and how they apply. These are your rights. Know them. Use them.

Low Income Taxpayer Clinics (LITCs) are independent from the IRS. LITCs represent individuals whose income is below a certain level and need to resolve tax problems with the IRS, such as audits, appeals, and tax collection disputes. In addition, clinics can provide information about taxpayer rights and responsibilities in different languages for individuals who speak English as a second language. Services are offered for free or a small fee. To find a clinic near you, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap or see IRS Publication 4134, Low Income Taxpayer Clinic List PDF.

Go to IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. View the amount you owe, pay online or set up an online payment agreement. Access your tax records online. Review the past 18 months of your payment history. Go to IRS.gov/SecureAccess to review the required identity authentication process.

Due to changes in the law, the IRS can’t issue refunds before mid-February 2018, for returns that properly claimed the earned income credit (EIC) or the additional child tax credit (ACTC). This applies to the entire refund, not just the portion associated with these credits.

Go to IRS.gov/Tools for the following. The Earned Income Tax Credit Assistant (IRS.gov/EIC) determines if you’re eligible for the EIC. The Online EIN Application (IRS.gov/EIN) helps you get an employer identification number. The IRS Withholding Calculator (IRS.gov/W4App) estimates the amount you should have withheld from your paycheck for federal income tax purposes. The First Time Homebuyer Credit Account Look-up (IRS.gov/HomeBuyer) tool provides information on your repayments and account balance. The Sales Tax Deduction Calculator (IRS.gov/SalesTax) figures the amount you can claim if you itemize deductions on Schedule A (Form 1040), choose not to claim state and local income taxes, and you didn’t save your receipts showing the sales tax you paid.

The IRS doesn’t initiate contact with taxpayers by email or telephone to request personal or financial information. This includes any type of electronic communication, such as text messages and social media channels. Go to IRS.gov/IDProtection for information and videos. If your SSN has been lost or stolen or you suspect you’re a victim of tax-related identity theft, visit IRS.gov/ID to learn what steps you should take.

This section describes the rights of taxpayers and the procedures for tax assessment, appeal, collection and refund of tax revenues and expenses.

A taxpayer has the right to expect that the tax system will take into account facts and circumstances that may affect his or her ability to meet his or her basic obligations, pay, or provide information in a timely manner. A taxpayer has the right to receive assistance from the Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) if he or she encounters financial difficulties or if the IRS fails to resolve his or her tax issues in a timely and appropriate manner through normal channels.
The taxpayer has the right to pay only the taxes paid and paid, including interest and penalties, and to demand that the IRS properly use the taxes paid.

Because taxpayers have the right to file a fair and impartial administrative appeal against most IRS decisions, including multiple penalties, and because they have the right to receive a written response from the IRS Independent Appeals Office to their decisions. Generally, taxpayers have the right to take their cases to court.

It is the duty of taxpayers to consider any investigation, review, or enforcement action by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) as lawfully necessary and to respect all due process rights, including search and seizure protections, and to provide for retrospective due process hearings, where applicable.

The taxpayer has the right to expect that any information that he or she provides to the IRS will not be disclosed, except where the taxpayer or the law authorizes it. The taxpayer has the right to expect that appropriate punitive action will be taken against employees, returns processors, or other persons who misuse or disclose the taxpayer's return information.

Taxpayers have the right to hire an agent of their choice to represent them in the IRS. If they cannot afford the agent's fees, they have the right to seek assistance from the Low Income Taxpayer Service.

The highest net income for self-employed persons in the Social Security portion of the self-employment tax is $176,100 in 2025. The standard mileage rate is $176,100. The operating cost of commercial cars, trucks, pickups, or vans is 70 cents per mile in 2025 (the standard mileage rate).

For more information, please visit the 8886 Form Explanation or the Tax Center for Tax Evasion and Abuse of Tax Evasion Programs and Transactions (SB/SE). Do you need help with tax issues or preparing a tax return, or do you need a free publication or form? The SB/SE Tax Center provides taxpayers who file the following forms, as well as taxpayers who are small business owners with less than $10 million in assets: Form 1040; Form 1040-SR; Form C, E, F, or 2106 (except for taxable income). For more information, please visit the SB/SE Tax Center (except for taxable income taxation) which is a tax-exempt entity (except for taxable income taxation) which is taxed at a flat-rate rate of $1.00 per hour.

The IRS is a proud partner of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children® (NCMEC). Photos of missing children selected by the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children may appear on pages that would otherwise be blank in this publication. If you know a child, you can help bring them home by viewing the photos and calling 1-800-THE-LOST (1-800-843-5678).

After you have calculated your operating income and expenses, you are ready to calculate your net profit or net loss for the business. You can deduct operating expenses from operating income. If your expenses are less than your income, the difference is net profit and becomes part of your income on line 3 of Schedule 1 (Table 1040). If your expenses are more than your income, the difference is a net loss.

Income from your trade or business may be limited to your income from profit or loss. If there is a loss, use Table 461 to determine the amount of your excess operating loss. Your excess operating loss will be included as income in Schedule 1 (Table 1040) line 8p and treated as a net operating loss (NOL) that you must turn over and deduct in the following year.

If you are operating a business that is not profitable, there are limits to the deductions you can make. You cannot use your activity losses to offset other income. Your hobbies or main sports or recreational activities are within this limit. For details on non-profit activities, see Hobbies or business activities: Doing a side job.
The self-employment tax rules apply regardless of your age, even if you are already receiving social security and health insurance benefits.

Generally, if your net self-employment income is $400 or more, you must pay income tax on self-employment and file an income tax return (Form 1040) using the income tax return (Form SE) to calculate your net self-employment income.
If you are a self-employed sole proprietor or an independent contractor, you will normally use Appendix C (form 1040) to calculate your income from employment tax.
The self-employment tax rate on net income in 2024 is 15.3% (VAT 12.4% social security tax plus 2.9% health insurance tax).

If your salary and tips are subject to Social Security tax or Railroad Retirement Tax Part 1 or both, and the total amount is not less than $168,600, you do not have to pay the Social Security tax portion of 12.4%, Social Security tax or Railroad Retirement Tax Part 1 (optional combination of three). If your salary and tips are subject to Social Security tax or Railroad Retirement Tax Part 1 or both, and the total amount is not less than $168,600, you do not have to pay the Social Security tax portion of 12.4%, Social Security tax or Railroad Retirement Tax Part 1 (optional combination of three).

If your self-employment net income exceeds the threshold for the deductible, you may be required to pay an additional health insurance tax of 0.9% (depending on your tax status). For more information, see the Self-Employment (SE) Tax, Tax") in Chapter 1 and Form 8959 and its notes.

In general, U.S. residents are required to pay self-employment tax under the same rules as U.S. citizens. Non-U.S. residents are not required to pay self-employment tax unless a valid international social security agreement (also known as a comprehensive agreement) establishes that they are covered by the U.S. social security system. However, residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, or American Samoa are considered U.S. residents for this purpose and are required to pay self-employment tax because they are considered taxable U.S. residents. For more information about foreigners, see the Pet Expatriates Tax Guide, Publication 519, which was published in

If you have income from more than one trade, business or profession that is subject to income tax, you must add up the net profit (or loss) from all sources to determine your total income subject to income tax. A loss in one business reduces your profit from the other business.

If any income from a trade or business (except income from a joint venture) is considered income from common property under state law, it is included in the income for which the spouse engaged in the trade or business is liable to pay self-employment tax.

Income or losses arising from the sale of property that is neither a trading stock nor primarily used for the sale of property to a customer shall not be included in income payable on the basis of the income from employment tax. It does not matter whether the disposal is a sale, exchange or involuntary conversion.

If you are self-employed and you reduce or cease your business activities, the insurance compensation or other payments you receive for loss of business income are included in the income payable as income from employment tax. If you are not working when you receive the payment, the payment is still related to your business and is included in the income payable as income from employment tax, even if your business is temporarily stopped.

If you work for a church or a church-controlled organization (except as a pastor, clergyman, or Christian Science practitioner) that elects to be exempt from Social Security and Medicare taxes, you will be required to pay self-employment tax if you receive $108.28 or more in salary from the church or organization. For more information, see the publication Social Security and Other Information for Clergy and Religious Workers, No. 517.

You are not required to pay self-employment tax for the expenses you have incurred as a notary (see the explanatory note on form 1040) in Schedule C).
If you are employed by a state or local government and are paid for your services on a fee-only basis, you are required to pay self-employment tax.

If you are a U.S. citizen working in the United States, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, or the U.S. Virgin Islands and your employer is a foreign government, a wholly owned foreign government agency, or an international organization, your employer is not required to deduct Social Security and Medicare taxes from your wages.

If you are a self-employed U.S. citizen or resident alien living outside the United States, you must pay self-employment tax in most cases. When calculating self-employment tax, self-employed foreign income cannot be reduced by the exemption of foreign income.

The United States has social security agreements with many countries that eliminate double taxation of both types of social security. Under these agreements, you generally must pay Social Security and Medicare taxes in the country where you live. The country where you must pay taxes will issue you a certificate as proof that you are exempt from paying Social Security taxes in other countries.

Using the optional method may increase your self-employment tax. If you pay more self-employment tax, you may receive more benefits in retirement. Since the deduction is used for Form 1040 or half of the self-employment tax on Form 1040-SR, using the optional method may also increase your adjusted gross income (AGI), which will affect your eligibility for credit, deduction, or other purposes that are limited by the AGI. Using and not using the optional method to calculate your AGI, see if the optional method is beneficial to you.

To calculate your net income using the conventional method, multiply your self-employed income by 92.35% (0.9235). See your Schedule SE (Form 1040) line 4a for information on how to calculate your net income using the conventional method. Net income calculated using the conventional method is also known as actual net income.

However, if you are a general partner or if the amount reported on the K-1 form is a loss, you need to adjust the amount.

You can report less than the sum of your actual net earnings from farming and nonfarming income, but not less than the sum of your actual net earnings from nonfarming income. If you use both methods, you can report no more than $6,920 as your total net earnings from self-employment.

If you use a tax year that is not a calendar year, you must use the tax rate and maximum income limit that were in effect at the beginning of your tax year. If the tax rate or maximum income limit changes during your tax year, you must continue to use the same tax rate and limit throughout the tax year.

You may use the Form SE (Form 1040) to calculate and report your self-employment tax. If you file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, you may enter the self-employment tax in the fourth line of Form 2 and attach Form SE to your form. If you file Form 1040-SS, you may enter the SE tax in the third line and attach Form SE to your form. If you are required to pay SE tax, you may file Form 1040, 1040-SR or Form 1040-SS, even if you are not required to file a federal income tax return.

If you file a joint return, you cannot file a joint supplementary return SE. This applies regardless of whether one or both spouses have income tax liability for self-employment tax. If both spouses have income tax liability for self-employment tax, you must file a separate supplementary return SE.

If you are engaged in more than one trade or business, you must add up the net profits (or losses) from each business to calculate your self-employment tax. A loss in one business will reduce your profits from another business.
This chapter explains the process of inspection, appeal, collection and refund.

We accept most tax returns submitted by taxpayers. ❚ If we investigate your return, or choose to examine the return, it does not mean that you are dishonest. ❚ An investigation or examination may or may not result in more taxes. ❚ We can end your case without any changes, or you can receive a refund. ❚ The process of selecting a return for review usually begins in one of two ways. ❚ One is that we use a computer program to identify the tax return for which there may be an error. ❚ These procedures may be based on tax returns, such as Form 1099 and Form W-2, research on past inspections, or other specific projects. ❚ Another way is to use information from a regulated program to indicate that there may be errors in the return. ❚ These sources may include public records, and personal information. ❚ If we determine that the information is accurate and reliable, we can choose to use the 556 check your return. ❚ The first section of the tax return, which is the procedure for examining the return, explains how we can do it, and gives you the information you need. ❚ These procedures may be based on tax returns that are incorrect. ❚ These procedures may be based on tax returns that are based on past inspections, or other studies, or other projects. ❚ These procedures may be based on the same, but they may be used by the same person. ❚ These procedures are based on the same. ❚ The process.

If we have checked your tax return and found the same item in any year for the previous 2 years and we propose not to make any changes to your tax liability, please contact us as soon as possible so that we can know whether we should discontinue the check.

If you do not agree with the changes, you can appeal to the IRS Independent Appeals Office. ⠀ Most disputes can be resolved without costly and time-consuming court proceedings. ⠀ Your right to appeal is detailed in Issue 5 and How to prepare for a protest, Issue 556. ⠀ If you do not want to appeal to the Appeals Office or disagree with its findings, you can appeal to the US Tax Court, Federal Claims Court or US District Court where you live. ⠀ If you appeal to the court, the IRS is responsible for proving certain facts. ⠀ If you agree with your opinion on most issues and find that our position is wrong, you can recover the administrative costs and fees without any further action. ⠀
For more information on your right to appeal, see the Tax Appeal Law in the Official Gazette No. 1660 (in Finnish).

In general, you and your spouse are jointly or separately liable for all taxes, interest, or penalties due on your joint tax return. To seek compensation for legal liabilities relating to your spouse (or ex-spouse), you must file a claim on Form 8857 for the innocent spouse relief claim. In some cases, Form 8857 may be required to be filed within 2 years of the IRS' first attempt to charge you.

The IRS generally deals directly with you or your authorized representative. However, if we need information that you cannot provide, or to verify information that we have received, we will sometimes talk to others. If we contact other people, for example, neighbors, banks, employers, or employees, we will usually need to tell them limited information, such as your name. The law prohibits us from disclosing any information beyond what is necessary to obtain or verify the information we are looking for. We may still need to contact others as long as your case requires further action. If we do contact others, you have the right to request a list of those contacted. You can make a request by phone, in writing, or during a personal conversation.

If you think you have paid too much tax, you can file a tax refund. Generally, you must file within 3 years of the original filing date, or within 2 years of the filing date (whichever is later). More information on refunds is available in Publication No. 556. If you are entitled to a refund but you have not filed a tax return, you must file a tax refund within two years of paying the tax.
If you have questions about your taxes, need help with your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, go to IRS.gov for resources that can help you immediately.

Once you have received all of your salary and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); unemployment compensation statements (in mailed or digital format) or other government payment statements (Form 1099-G); and interest, dividend, and pension statements from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you can choose from several options to prepare and file your tax return. You can either prepare your own tax return, check if you qualify for exemption, or hire a tax professional to prepare your tax return.

Taxpayers who need information about our services and their procedures should contact us at 833-690-0598. The Help Line can answer questions about current and future products and services that are available in alternative media formats (e.g., Braille, large print, audio, etc.). The Help Line does not have access to your IRS account. For help with tax laws, refunds, or account-related issues, please visit IRS.gov/UsLetHelp.
Please visit IRS.gov/DisasterRelief to see the current disaster tax relief.

You need an IRS Online Account (OLA) to complete your mobile-friendly form that requires your signature. You can choose to submit the form online or download a copy for mailing. You will need your file scanned to support your submission. For more information, go to IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms.

Go to IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. Browse the amount you owe and break it down by tax year. View payment plan details or apply for a new payment plan. Make payments or view 5-year payment history and any pending or scheduled payments. View your tax records, including key data from your most recent tax return and tax forms. View digital copies of notices selected by the IRS. Approve or reject authorization requests from tax professionals. View your file address or manage your communication preferences.

To access information to help you with your tax season, you can use your online account. You can get a receipt, view your most recently filed tax return, and get adjusted gross income. Go to IRS.gov/Account to create or access your online account.
This tool allows your tax professional to submit an authorization request to access your individual taxpayer's IRS online account (OLA). For more information, please visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

The IRS cannot issue refunds on tax returns for which an EIC or additional child tax credit (ACTC) was not properly applied for before mid-February. This time frame applies to full refunds, not just partial refunds related to these credits.

IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax directly from your checking or savings account without charging you anything. Debit, credit, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor, pay online or by phone. Electronic Refund: Provide payment arrangements using tax form software or through a tax professional when filing federal taxes. Federal e-tax filing system: This is the best option for businesses. Registration is required. Checks or money orders: You can send the money to the notices or statements listed above.

You can use the IRS.gov/Payments form to request an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) so that you can pay your taxes in monthly installments if you cannot pay them in full today. You can use the IRS.gov/Payments form to see if you can pay your tax debt in less than the full amount you owe. For more information about the OPA program, please visit IRS.gov/ICO.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). TAS helps taxpayers resolve issues with the IRS, makes administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or correct problems, and protects taxpayer rights. We work to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and to ensure that you are aware of and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Advocacy Act. We are your representatives at the IRS.

The Taxpayer Bill of Rights describes the ten basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. For more information about these rights, what they mean to you, and how they apply to specific IRS situations you may encounter, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate. IRS.gov/Taxpayer-Rights. The TAS is dedicated to protecting the rights of taxpayers and ensuring that the IRS enforces tax laws in a fair and just manner.

The Social Security Administration (SSA) provides a quick, free, and secure W-2 filing option for registered accountants, accountants, registered agents, and individuals processing Form W-2 (Wage and Tax Return) and Form W-2c (Correct Wage and Tax Return) on its website at SSA.gov/employer.

If you are a sole proprietor, partnership, or S corporation, you can view tax information in the IRS records and take further action using your business tax account. For more information, visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount.
