For those tax years in which the tax is waived, the taxpayer may choose to file a tax return for the tax year in which the tax is waived, but the taxpayer may not file a tax return for the tax year in which the tax is waived. If the taxpayer has not filed a tax return for the tax year in which the tax is waived, the taxpayer may file a tax return for the tax year in which the tax is waived.
The following discussion describes how to deal with other types of business income that you may receive.

A restricted property is one that is subject to specific restrictions that affect its value. If you receive restricted stock or other property as a result of services provided, the fair market value of the property in excess of the cost of the restriction is included in your income when the restriction is lifted. However, you may elect to be taxed in the year you receive the property. For more information on how to include a restricted property in income, see the Taxable Income and Non-Taxable Income section of Issue 525.
This does not apply to depreciation. You must collect the depreciation in accordance with the following rules.
You must repay the depreciation deduction in the following cases:

If your business utilization of the property listed (described under depreciation in Chapter 8) falls to 50% or less in the tax year following the tax year in which you put it into use, you may be required to recover a portion of the depreciation deduction. To do this, you may count the portion of the depreciation deduction you made in the previous years in the income statement in Schedule C. Use the fourth part of Form 4797 to calculate the amount specified in Schedule C. For more information, see Chapter 5 of Publication No. 946, What are the business use requirements? Contents.

If you are unmarried and you do not make a Section 179 deduction on your assets (discussed under depreciation in Chapter 8), and you must recover the Section 179 deduction before the end of the asset recovery period and before the business utilization rate falls to 50% or less. To do this, you can include the portion of the deduction you made in the income statement in Schedule C. Use the fourth part of Form 4797 to calculate the amount noted in Schedule C. See Chapter 2 of Publication No. 946 for information on when you can recover the deduction.

If you sell or exchange property that is depreciated against the gain, you may be required to treat all or part of the gain arising from the depreciation as ordinary income. You will calculate the gain arising from the depreciation on the third part of Form 4797. For more information, see Publication No. 544, Chapter 4.

A bill of exchange, other document of debt, issued to you when you sell or exchange stock or property primarily for the purpose of selling it to a customer, as stated in Schedule C. Normally, you would declare them at the principal amount (less any undisclosed interest) or issue price (for debt instruments with an OID) they indicate when you receive them.

If you reduce or cease your business activity, please declare in Schedule C any loss of business income that you receive from insurance or other sources. Even if your business is inactive at the time you receive the payment, you should declare the amount received in Schedule C.
You must count in your total income any compensation you receive in the tax year for any of the following losses caused by your business:

You may be entitled to a deduction from your income if it compensates you for the actual economic loss suffered. Your deduction is the lesser of: The amount of compensation you received or owed for the tax year less the amount you paid or incurred to recover compensation for the loss in the tax year.

If you receive any rebates, please include them in your income in the Income Statement in Appendix C. However, do not include them if you consider them to be deductions from related expenditure items, capital expenditure or the cost of goods sold, as appropriate.

If you have recovered bad debts or any other items deducted from your income for the previous year, you should include the recovered item in your income in Schedule C. However, if the total or partial deduction for the previous years did not reduce your tax, you may exclude the portion of your tax that was not reduced. If you exclude partial recoveries from your income, you must indicate a calculation formula on your tax return to reflect how you calculated the exclusion.
In some cases, the property or money you receive is not income.
The increase in the value of your property is not income until you realise the increase in value through sale or other taxable disposal.

If the tenant builds a building or repairs your property, the value of the property that is increased by the repairs is not your income. However, if the facts show that the repairs are rent paid to you, the value that is increased is income.
The money borrowed through a goodwill loan is not income.
The state and local sales tax that you collect and pay to the state or local government is not income.

A sale is a transaction whereby goods are sold to someone else for your own account. The ownership of the goods remains with you (the sender) even after the receiver has taken possession of the goods. Therefore, if you ship goods by mail order, you do not generate any profit or loss until the recipient sells the goods. The goods you ship by mail order are counted toward your inventory until they are sold. Do not count the goods you receive by mail order toward your inventory. If you sell goods or receive a profit or commission, depending on the accounting method you use, please count the profit or commission for your goods as your revenue.

Certain federal Medicaid deductions reported to you on Form 1099-MISC or Form 1099-NEC may not be taxable. For more information on how to report these payments, see the instructions in Appendix C (Form 1040).

If you have a lease signed after 5 August 1997 and you receive a construction allowance from the landlord in either of the following two cases: (i) in cash or in the form of a rent reduction, you may deduct it from your income. (ii) if you have a short-term retail space lease. (iii) if you have a long-term real estate property built or renovated on the retail space for your business use.

A lease agreement is a lease for retail space that is not for a term exceeding 15 years. The following provisions apply to determining whether the lease term is for a term not exceeding 15 years. In determining whether the lease term is for a term not exceeding 15 years, consideration shall be given to the option of a renewal.
Retail space is the property that you rent, occupy or otherwise use as a tenant in the sale of tangible personal property or services to the public.
Conditional real estate is non-residential property that is part of your retail space or otherwise appears in your retail space and is returned to the landlord at the end of the lease.

You must declare this income whether or not it is reported to you on the tax return. You are a direct seller if you meet all of the following conditions: 1. You engage in one of the following transactions or businesses: 2. You sell or solicit the sale of consumer goods at other locations of the residence or nonpermanent retail establishment, or sell or solicit the sale of consumer goods to any buyer for resale purposes at other locations of the residence or nonpermanent retail establishment by way of a commission.

If you are an options or commodities trader, you report gains and losses on transactions in section 1256 contracts (regulated futures contracts, foreign currency contracts, non-equity options, dealer equity options and dealer securities futures contracts) or property associated with those contracts (for example, shares used in hedging options) in Schedule C. For more information, see sections 1256 and 1402 (i).

If you are a trader in securities or commodities (including if you are a trader in securities or commodities and you have made a choice under section 475 (f) to calculate the market price), and you have disposed of securities or commodities, then you are a trader in securities or commodities. If you have not declared any gain or loss on the securities or commodities you have disposed of, you are not a trader in securities or commodities. For more information on a trader in securities or commodities, see Publication No. 550, Investment income and expenses, and Subject 429, Securities trader.
If the costs do not meet the requirements above, please declare the relevant costs in line 8z of the relevant Schedule 1 (Form 1040) of the relevant Annex to the Act.

If you meet all of the following conditions, you as a former self-employed insurance agent receive severance payments from the insurance company for your services to the insurance company, which are not declared in Schedule C. After the termination of your agreement to provide services to the company, you receive information about the severance payments. You did not provide any services to the company during the period after the termination of your service agreement until the end of the year in which you received the payments. You entered into a contract not to compete with the company for at least 1 year from the date of termination of the service agreement. The amount of the payments depends mainly on whether you sold the policies in the last year of the service agreement or registered them in your account, or whether these policies remained valid for a period of time after the termination of your service agreement, or both. The amount of the payments is not dependent on the service year or the total income generated by the company for the services provided (whether the services are received is dependent on the eligibility for the service year).

The income paid to the retired self-employed insurance agent by the insurance company is reported in Appendix C in proportion to the commission received by the retired self-employed insurance agent before retirement. In addition, sales continuation and deferral commissions paid before retirement are usually reported in Appendix C. However, the continuation commissions paid to the estate of the insurance agent are not reported in Appendix C.

You must declare the expenses you have received for the services you have provided as a notary public in Schedule C. These expenses are not subject to personal income tax (see the instructions in Schedule SE (Form 1040)).

Public employees are generally not required to declare their income while in public office on Schedule C. This provision applies to payments received from public funds by elected taxpayers in a fixed proportion of the taxes collected. Public office includes any elected or appointed office in the United States or a territory of the United States, the District of Columbia, a state or its political subdivision, or any wholly-funded agency of any of these. If state or local government employees are paid only in fee form and their services qualify for social security under a federal-state agreement, but are not included within its scope, they should declare their expenses from the public on Schedule C.

Income accounting for income tax purposes is sometimes different from accounting for financial purposes. This section discusses some common differences that may affect business transactions. Calculate your business income by tax year based on your usual accounting methods (see Chapter 2). If product sales are a revenue factor in your business, you generally must use inventory to clearly reflect your income.
All income you receive is taxable. You cannot avoid paying taxes by paying income to a third party.

You must calculate all purchases annually using the method you have chosen. If you use the second method, the creditor balance in your account at the end of the tax year is business income. Using this method, your cost of goods sold is not reduced by the corresponding amount due to the receipt of a cash discount.

The reduction in the list or catalogue price is usually not written into the invoice or charged to the customer. Do not record these discounts in your books. Instead, use only the net amount as the cost of purchasing the goods. For more information, see the Transaction Discounts in Chapter 6.

If the buyer of your property deposits part or all of the purchase price in the trust, you do not count any part of it in the total sale until you actually or presumably receive it. However, after the contract and the terms of the trust agreement are completed, you will generate taxable income even if you do not receive this money until next year.
When calculating net sales, you take into account the benefits you receive for returning the goods and any other benefits you receive from the sales.
The special provisions for the use of accrual accounting treatment for the treatment of received advances are discussed in Chapter 2, Accrual method.

If you manufacture or purchase goods for sale, you may deduct the cost of selling the goods from your total income in Schedule C. However, to determine these costs, you must evaluate your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year. If you are a manufacturer, wholesaler, or retailer, or if you engage in any business that manufactures, purchases, or sells goods to generate income, this chapter applies to you. This chapter does not apply to a personal service business, such as a doctor, lawyer, carpenter, or oil painter business, etc. However, if you are in a personal service business and also sell materials and supplies that you typically use in your business, or charges for them, this chapter applies to you. There are some exceptions for small business taxpayers, which may change the way your business calculates the cost of selling the goods. For more information, see Section 2.

If you donate inventory (property you sell in the course of your business), you can claim an amount of the donation deduction as its fair market value or its basis on the date of your donation (whichever is less accurate). The basis of the donation inventory is the inventory generated in the previous year. You will count any costs in the inventory at the beginning of the year of the donation.

The difference between the list price of the item and the price actually paid is called the transaction discount. When calculating the cost of purchase, you must use the payment price (rather than the list price). Do not list the discount amount separately as an item in gross revenue.

A cash discount is an amount that a supplier allows you to deduct from a purchase invoice in order to pay it on time. There are two accounting methods for handling cash discounts. You can either write it into a separate discount account or deduct it from the total purchase price for that year.

If you withdraw goods for personal or household use, you must deduct this cost from the total amount of goods you purchase for sale. For this purpose, you can record the cost of the goods you withdraw for personal use in your purchase or sales account. You must also record this amount in your withdrawal account. The withdrawal account is a separate account that you should keep to record the business income you withdraw to pay for personal and household expenses.

Direct labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who spend all their time directly on the manufacture of the product. They also include the part of the wages you pay to part-time employees who work directly on the product, provided you can determine the corresponding part of the wages.

Indirect labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who perform general factory functions that have no direct connection to the manufacture of marketable products, but are a necessary part of the manufacturing process.

Administrative expenses include rent, heating, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor, and oversight costs. Administrative expenses that you incur as a direct and necessary part of your manufacturing business are included in the cost of selling your goods.

Gross profit is calculated after gross revenues (Chapter 5) and costs of goods sold (Chapter 6). Gross profit must be determined before any operating expenses can be deducted. These expenses are discussed in Chapter 8.

Net income is calculated first, then gross profit is calculated. In Appendix C, total revenue (row 1) minus any refunds and allowances (row 2) is calculated to give net income (row 3). Refunds and allowances include cash or loan refunds, rebates, and other allowances you pay to customers other than the actual selling price.

The cost of goods sold is the difference between the cost of goods sold divided by the total revenue received (the difference between the cost of goods sold divided by the total revenue received, excluding any refunds, discounts, or other benefits) and the cost of goods sold divided by the total revenue received. Most professions and businesses that sell services, but not products, can calculate gross profit in this way directly from net revenue.
The following graph shows how gross profit is calculated in the gross profit section of the Retail Operating Income Statement:

At the end of each business day, make sure that the amount recorded is balanced against the actual cash and credit income for the day. You may find it helpful to use cash registers to record income. You should also use a proper invoicing system and open a separate bank account for your business.

Check to ensure that the sales tax is correctly recorded. If you collect state and local sales taxes from a buyer that are collected from you as the seller of the goods or services, you must count the amount collected in total revenue. If you are required to collect state and local taxes from a buyer and hand them over to the state or local government, you generally should not count these amounts in revenue.

Checks to ensure that your inventory inventory procedures are appropriate. These procedures should ensure that all items are accounted for in inventory and that the pricing methods used are appropriate. Use inventory tables and bill of lading as the only evidence of inventory. Inventory tables can be purchased from office supply stores. The inventory table contains a list of items that records the description, quantity, unit price, and value of each item in the inventory.

If you are in a retail or wholesale business, you can check the accuracy of your gross profit. First, you divide gross profit by net revenue. The percentage you get represents the average price difference between the cost of selling the goods and the selling price. Next, compare that percentage with your price-adding strategy. If the two percentages differ very little or not at all, your gross profit is accurate.

You are running a retail business. On average, you will add a price to your merchandise, so you will achieve a gross margin of 331/3% on sales. Its net income (total revenue minus refunds and allowances) listed on its income statement is $300,000. Its cost of goods sold is $200,000. Its gross margin is $100,000. Its cost of goods sold is $300,000. Its cost of goods sold is $200,000.

If your income is from revenues other than your normal business operations, enter this income in line 6 of Schedule C and add it to gross profit. The result is total revenues. Some examples include revenues from the interest checking account, revenues from the sale of waste, revenues from certain fuel tax benefits and refunds, and revenues recovered from bad accounts.

SEP, SIMPLE, and Conforming Plan offer you and your employees some form of tax credit for retirement savings. You may deduct contributions made to your employee plan in line 19 of Schedule C. If you are a sole proprietor, you may deduct contributions made to your own plan in Schedule 1 of Schedule 1040 of Schedule 16. If your plan contributions do not cover trustee fees, you may also deduct the deduction. Contributions Income is generally tax-free unless your employee contributes to the plan. Contributions Income is generally tax-free unless your employee contributes to the plan. If you start a new defined benefit or defined contribution plan (including a 401 (k) plan), simplified plan, or SEP plan, you may apply for a tax credit for retirement savings.

Rent is any sum paid by you for the use of property that is not yours. Normally, you can only deduct rent as a business expense if the rent is for the use of property that you use in your business. You cannot deduct rent if you own or will receive rights or ownership in the property.

You cannot deduct rent for an unreasonable rent. In general, a reasonableness issue arises only if you and the tenant are related. The rent is reasonable if the rent paid to the person concerned is the same as the amount you paid to a stranger for using the same property. The rent is reasonable only because it is calculated as a percentage of your total income. The persons concerned include your immediate relatives, including your siblings (brothers and sisters) and your spouse, ancestors, and direct descendants. For a list of other persons involved, see Section 267 of the Internal Revenue Code.
If you rent your home and use part of it as a business premises, you can deduct the rent you paid for that part. You must meet the commercial requirements of your home.

Usually, rent paid in the course of your business is deductible in the year in which it is paid or due. If you pay rent in advance, you can only deduct the amount related to the use of the rented property in the tax year.

You may deduct income tax on the total income (as distinguished from net income) directly attributable to your business on Schedule C. If you list your deductions item by item, you may deduct other state and local income taxes on Schedule A (Form 1040).

You can deduct social security tax, health insurance tax and FUTA tax paid by you as an employer out of your own money. Employment tax is discussed in more detail in Chapter 1. You can also deduct payments you make as an employer to the State Unemployment Compensation Fund or the State Disability Benefit Fund.

You can deduct any taxes levied by the state or local government on personal property used in your business from the Schedule C deduction. You can deduct the registration fee for the right to use the property in the state or local area.

The taxable income of a person who is not a resident of the state of New York is not deductible from the income of the state of New York, or from any sales tax paid by the person who is not a resident of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of the state of New York, or from the income of persons who are not residents of New York.

Taxes on gasoline, diesel, and other automotive fuels used by you in the course of your business are generally included in the cost of fuel. These taxes are not deductible as a separate item. You are entitled to a credit or refund of federal excise taxes paid by you for the use of fuel for certain purposes. For more information, see Publication No. 510
You can deduct the cost of travel by air, train, bus or car to and from your place of residence and business.
You can deduct the cost of business calls during your travel, including business communications via fax machines or other communication devices.

You are a resident of the United States and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States, and you are a resident of the United States.
For more information on these exceptions, see the policy on the use of your home for commercial purposes in the No. 587 publication.

If, after considering the place where you work, your residence cannot be determined as your principal place of business, you cannot deduct the expenses of the family office. However, for information on the eligibility for the deduction of the expenses of the family office, see No. 587.

Generally, you must capitalize the cost of acquiring or producing physical or tangible personal property used in your trade or business, such as buildings, equipment, or furniture. However, if you choose to use the minimum safe harbor for tangible assets, you may deduct the minimum amount you paid for the acquisition or production of certain tangible assets for financial accounting purposes or for the purpose of maintaining your books and records. If you have an applicable financial statement, you may use the safe harbor to deduct the amount paid for the purchase of tangible assets, up to $5,000 per item or per invoice. If you do not have an applicable financial statement, you may use the minimum safe harbor to deduct the amount paid for the purchase of tangible assets, up to $2,500 per item or per invoice.
For information on the minimum safe harbour requirements for making this choice and using the TPP, see the TPP Regulations.

You may also deduct the following expenses:  Advertising  Bank fees  Contributions to commercial organizations  Education expenses  Disability-related expenses  Interview expenses  Subsidies  Licensing and regulatory fees  Mobile machinery  Job transfer services  Payments and fines you have paid for delayed or non-performing contracts  Repair and maintenance of real or personal tangible property  Repayment of income  Materials and materials  Utilities 

You generally cannot deduct the following: business expenses: rent and returns: charitable donations: demolition expenses or losses: business, social, sports, lunch, sports, aviation and hotel club memberships: entertainment expenses: improvements to real or tangible personal property: improvement projects are payments made to improve your property, repair your property, or perform work to make your property suitable for a new or different use: lobbying expenses: fines and penalties you pay to a government agency or agency for breaking the law: personal, life and family expenses: political contributions: settlements or payments related to sexual harassment or abuse, if the settlement or payment is bound by a confidentiality agreement: you cannot also pay the settlement or related attorney's fees.

If someone owes you money and you cannot get it back, you have a bad debt. Bad debt is divided into two types: business and non-business bad debt. Business bad debt is usually a debt resulting from a transaction or business operation.

If your principal motivation for incurring debt is business, the debt is closely related to your business. Business bad debts are caused primarily by sales to customers, and may also be caused by loans to suppliers, customers, employees, or distributors. List the goods and services that customers have not paid for as receivables or receipts on your books. If you cannot recover any part of these receivables or receipts, the part that cannot be recovered is a business bad debts. You can only deduct the amount you owe from these receivables and receipts if you include the amount owed in your total income for the year or year before you file your deduction.

If you claim a bad deduction on your income tax return and then recover all or part of it, you may have to count the amount you recovered in whole or in part toward your total income. However, you may exclude the amount of the deduction that was not deducted from your tax. Report the recovered amount as Other income on the appropriate business form or appendix. For more information, see Recovered on item 525.

If the bad account deduction is increased by a NOL that has not expired by the beginning of the tax year in which the recall is made, you will treat the deduction as a reduction in your tax. The bad account deduction for the NOL helps reduce the tax for the year in which you hold the NOL. For more information on the individual NOL, see Publication 536. See also the notes to Form 1045 and Form 1139.

All other bad accounts are non-operating bad accounts and are deductible as short-term capital losses on the balance sheet on Form 8949 and Appendix D (Form 1040). For more information on non-operating bad accounts, see Section 166 and its provisions.

If you use the accrual accounting method, you usually declare your income when you receive it. If you have already included the amount that cannot be collected in your income, you can deduct the bad debts from the accounts receivable that cannot be collected.

If you use the cash accounting method, you do not usually declare your income when you receive the payment. You cannot deduct bad debts from your income if you have never counted them against your income.

If you sell the business but retain its accounts receivable, these debts are business debts because they are generated by your trade or business. If these accounts receivable subsequently become worthless, the loss is still a business bankruptcy.

Losses caused by debts of the business acquired from the deceased, whose nature is determined in the same way as the debts acquired by the business acquired. If the debts become worthless are closely related to the trade or business of the deceased, the executor of the deceased's estate will treat any losses caused by the debts as business bad debts. Otherwise, the loss of these debts will become non-business bad debts of the deceased's estate.
If you borrow money from a customer, supplier, employee or dealer for business reasons and you try to collect the money but are unable to do so, you have a bad business.

You are entitled to a bad debt deduction only if you meet all of the following requirements: 1) you have used the accounting method of the right to collect; 2) the debt is incurred as a result of the sale of goods or services by you in the ordinary course of trade or business; 3) more than 30% of the sales receivable in the year of the sale is from sales to the party; 4) you have made a substantial and sustained effort to collect the debt;
You cannot claim a bad debts deduction if the facts and circumstances show that the loan you made to the company was in fact an investment in capital.

If your business partnership breaks up and one of your former partners is unable to pay, you may be required to pay more than the partnership's debt, which you share proportionally. If you pay any part of the bankrupt partner's debt, you may claim a bad debts deduction for the amount you paid that is part of the bankrupt partner's share.

You are entitled to a business bankruptcy if the debt you secured subsequently becomes worthless and you meet all of the following requirements: You made the security in the course of trade or business; You have a legal obligation to repay the debt; You made the security before the debt became worthless; You meet this requirement if you reasonably expect not to have to repay the debt if the borrower fails to pay it in full; You receive reasonable compensation for making the security; You meet this requirement if you made the security in accordance with the normal course of business or in the best interests of the business;

When you pay a loan that is secured, you may have the right to replace the lender. You then become the creditor of the debt. If you have this or other claims on the borrower, you cannot claim a bad debts deduction until these claims become partially or completely worthless.
If you are owed money by two or more debtors and you cannot collect the money from one of them, the amount cannot be deducted as a bad debt.
If the sale price of the mortgaged or pledged property is less than the debt, the balance of the debt that is not repaid and cannot be collected is considered a bad debt.

If you receive property in partial debt settlement, reduce the debt by the FMV of the property, and the FMV will become the basis of the property. If and when the remaining debt becomes worthless, you can deduct it as bad debt. If you later sell the property for more than its base, any proceeds from the sale will be attributed to the increase in value of the property.

If you use a specific overdraft method, you can deduct some or all of the bad debts of a particular business that become worthless during the tax year. However, for some of the worthless bad debts, your deduction is limited to the amount you overdraft on your books for that year.

You may deduct specific bad debts that are partially uncollectible during the tax year. Your tax deduction is limited to the amount you write off from your books that year. You do not have to write off and deduct the portion of the worthless debts every year. You can defer the write-off until a later year. However, you cannot deduct any portion of the debts after the year in which the debts become completely worthless.

If the debt becomes worthless in the current tax year, you can deduct the entire amount of the debt minus any amount deducted in a previous tax year when the debt was only partially worthless. You do not have to actually write off the account on the books, so you can deduct the bad debt for a completely worthless debt. However, you may want to actually write off the account on the books.

If you are unable to manage your finances because of a physical or mental disability, you may need more time to submit your application. Such disability must be proven. For the relevant details and more information on filing a return, please see Publication 556.
If you have an office in your home that can be your main place of business, your workplace can be your home. For more information, see the section on using your home for business purposes below.

You can use the standard mileage rate to calculate the deductible operating costs for a commercial van, van, pickup truck, or van. The standard mileage rate for commercial vehicles is 67 cents per mile for 2024. If you choose to use the standard mileage rate for one year, you cannot deduct actual expenses for that year except for business-related parking and commuting expenses.

If you use the standard mileage rate for your own car or truck, you must choose to use it for the first year that the car is available for your business. In later years, you can choose to use the standard mileage rate or the actual expense. If you choose to use the standard mileage rate for your leased car, you must use the standard mileage rate for the entire lease period (including the renewal lease period).

You cannot use the standard mileage rate if you: 1. operate five or more trailers at the same time; 2. claim depreciation deductions using any method other than the Direct Line Act, such as ACRS or MACRS; 3. apply for a section 179 deduction for trailers; 4. apply for a special depreciation allowance for trailers; 5. declare actual carriage expenses for the trailers you rent; or 6. are a rural mail carrier who receives conditional reimbursement.

You can deduct any business-related parking and commuting expenses in addition to using the standard mileage rate. (Parking expenses paid when you park at your workplace are not deductible commuting expenses.)

If you acquire a property for use in a business that is expected to last more than one year, you generally cannot deduct all of the cost as an operating expense in the year you acquire the property. You must spread the cost over more than one tax year and deduct a portion of the cost each year in Schedule C. This method of deducting the cost of a business property is called depreciation.

You may depreciate property that meets all of the following requirements: ◦ must be property that you own ◦ must be used for business or capable of generating income ◦ you may never depreciate inventory (as described in Chapter 2), because it is not held for use in your business ◦ years of use must be significantly longer than the years it was put into use ◦ years of use must be determinable, which means it must be property that will wear out, decay, wear out, become obsolete, or lose value by natural causes ◦ you may never depreciate the cost of the land, because the land will not wear out, become obsolete, or be depleted ◦ cannot be excluded as property ◦ this includes property that was put into use and disposed of in the same year ◦

You may choose to treat certain repairs or replacements to your business or business as depreciable improvements. You may choose to do so if you treat these amounts as capital expenditures in the books and records that are commonly used to calculate income and expenses.

This depreciation method for most commercial and investment properties put into use after 1986 is called the modified accelerated cost recovery system (MACRS). The MACRS is discussed in detail in Publication 946.

You may elect to deduct a small amount of that property in the year in which you put a particular depreciated property into use. This deduction is known as the Section 179 deduction. In 2024, you may elect to deduct up to a maximum amount generally $1,220,000 (higher limits apply to specific properties). The limit is usually deducted for the portion of the cost of the property put into use in the tax year that exceeds $3,050,000. You may deduct a total amount of $12,400 for the depreciation of the return of the passenger car used in your business for the first time in 2024 (including the Section 179 deduction).

If you are applying for any of the following, use the 4562 Exemption and Amortization Exemption. Exemption for depreciation of property put into use during the current tax year. Section 179 deduction. Exemption for depreciation of any property listed (whenever put into use).
You cannot deduct your salary or any money you take out of your business for personal use. As a sole proprietor, you are not an employee of the business.

Some of the ways you pay employees are as follows:  bonuses  education expenses  benefits (discussed below)  loans or advances that you do not expect to be repaid by the employee (if those loans or advances are provided for personal services actually provided)  property that you transfer to the employee as service remuneration  employee business expenses reimbursement  sick leave pay  vacation pay 

You may deduct the additional benefits you provide in the appropriate cost category of Schedule C. For example, if you allow an employee to use a car or other property you rent, you may deduct the cost of the rental as a rental or rental expense. If you own the property, you may deduct the cost of the property or other basis as a Section 179 deduction or depreciation deduction.

You can generally deduct the premiums you pay for the following types of insurance related to your business: 1. fire, theft, flood or similar insurance; 2. credit insurance covering business bankruptcy losses; 3. employee group hospital and medical insurance, including long-term care insurance; 4. liability insurance; 5. medical accident insurance covering personal liability arising from injury or damage to a patient or customer as a result of professional negligence; 6. workers' compensation insurance, but regardless of whether there is any, must cover any claim for bodily injury or work-related illness to your employees in your business; 7. state unemployment insurance fund contributions if considered taxable under state law; 8. employee health insurance payments for the management of your business bankruptcy; 9. personal injury insurance for the management of your employee's disability or long-term care insurance; 11. insurance for the personal injury of your employee for the purpose of calculating your business expenses; You cannot deduct premiums for the following types of insurance: 1. Self-employed insurance reserves. You cannot deduct premiums for life insurance policies that are written as a reserve for self-employed insurance. You cannot deduct premiums for life insurance policies that are written as a reserve for life insurance policies that are written for or directly taken out by a person. This applies even if you cannot purchase business insurance for a specific business risk. However, you are not entitled to deduct premiums for your actual loss. For more information, see Publication No. 547.
You may be able to deduct the amount paid for medical and dental insurance and for conditional long-term care insurance for you and your family.

If you have obtained or are considering an insurance plan through the health insurance marketplace or in your company and you are applying for a tax credit for insurance premiums, please refer to Form 8962 and its separate instructions and use the publication No 974.

Why do certain taxpayers have to limit their deductions for business interest expenses? Please refer to the instructions for Form 8990 to determine whether you have to limit your deductions for business interest expenses, who is required to file Form 8990 and how certain businesses can choose not to comply with the limit on business interest expenses.

Other things to consider are: How to allocate interest between personal and business use; Restrictions on commercial interest; When to deduct interest; Provisions for loans that are below the market rate; Loans that are generally interest-free or interest-bearing at rates below the applicable federal rate.

If the costs of lawyers and professionals (e.g. those charged by accountants) are ordinary necessary expenses directly related to the operation of your business, you can deduct these costs in Schedule C. However, you cannot generally deduct the costs of lawyers for the acquisition of business assets. Please include these costs in the base of the property.

As a sole proprietor or statutory employee, you may deduct the cost of preparing the tax return part related to your business in Schedule C. As a sole proprietor or statutory employee, you may also deduct in Schedule C the amount you pay or incur when you settle the so-called tax difference for your business.

A non-resident alien is an individual who is not a U.S. citizen for tax purposes. A nonresident alien is defined as a non-tax resident and a tax resident. This publication is intended to help you determine your identity and provide you with the information you need to file your U.S. tax return. A tax resident is generally taxed on their worldwide income, on an equal basis with U.S. citizens. A nonresident alien is taxed only on income derived from within the United States, and on certain income related to the conduct of a trade or business in the United States.

We invite you to comment on this publication and to provide suggestions for future editions. You may send your comments to us at the following address: IRS.gov/FormComments. You may also write to the Internal Revenue Service Tax Forms and Publications 1111 Constitution Ave. NW, IR-6526 Washington, DC 20224 Although we cannot respond to every comment we receive individually, we appreciate your feedback and will consider your comments and suggestions as we modify the tax form, statements and publications.

The United States has suspended the implementation of Article 3, paragraph 1 (g) of the Tax Agreement. The remaining provisions of the Treaty will remain in effect. The suspension will take effect on December 17, 2024, and will continue until December 31, 2026, or may be extended if the two governments decide jointly. The partial suspension of the Income Tax Agreement with Russia. On June 17, 2024, the United States formally notified the Russian Federation of the suspension of the Agreement with Russia.

A non-tax resident is a person who is a resident of a country with which the United States has an income tax treaty (and who is a resident of certain tax treaties) and is eligible for certain benefits. Most treaties require that a non-tax resident be a resident of the treaty country in order to qualify for the benefit in the year in which the benefit is claimed. However, for certain students, interns, teachers, or researchers, some treaties require only that the non-tax resident be a resident of the treaty country prior to their admission to the United States.

The full text of individual tax treaties is also available at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. For more information about these tax treaties, please visit IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Tax-payers/Treaties-Tax-receiving benefits, which are usually available to you before you qualify for a tax deduction or elimination of income tax.

Non-tax law defines resident's agreement income as total income subject to taxation under the taxation agreement. Agreement income, including dividends originating in the United States, is taxed at a taxation agreement rate of no more than 15%. Non-tax law defines resident's income as total income subject to taxation under the taxation agreement. To determine the taxation of income subject to the lower taxation agreement, the taxation of income subject to the lower taxation agreement is calculated under the agreement.

The following paragraphs briefly describe the tax exemptions available under the tax treaty for personal service income, remittances, scholarships, grants, and capital gains income. The conditions for applying for the exemption vary by tax treaty. For more information about the conditions under the special tax treaty, download the full text of most U.S. tax treaties at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. The website also provides technical notes for many of these treaties. See also Publication 90 No. 1. The tax treaty benefits also cover interest, dividend, rent, franchise, pension and annuity income.

A non-tax resident who is a resident of a treaty country and who, under most income tax treaties, is a non-tax resident who is a resident of a treaty country and who, in the event of a draw in favour of a treaty country, is temporarily serving in the United States (see Chapter 1), and whose personal income is eligible for exemption from United States taxation in part or in full if it meets the requirements of the applicable treaty provisions.
Some income tax treaties contain different requirements, such as different maximum residence periods. For more information, see Publication No. 901.

Some income tax treaties contain provisions that allow residents of treaty countries to reside in the United States for no more than a certain number of days and exempt from U.S. taxation income earned as an independent contractor or self-employed person in the absence of a regularly available permanent headquarters in the United States.

Under many income tax treaties, temporary visiting non-tax law defines a resident alien faculty or professor whose primary purpose is to teach at a university or other accredited educational institution, and whose remuneration for teaching received during the two or three years preceding their arrival in the United States is exempt from U.S. income tax. Many treaties also provide for exemptions for participation in research. Typically, the faculty or professor must be primarily engaged in teaching, lecturing, mentoring, or engaged in research work in the United States.

All agreements have provisions for the exemption of certain types of income earned by employees of foreign governments. However, there are differences between the agreements as to who is eligible for this benefit. Under many agreements, foreign nationals who are defined as residents under the tax code are not eligible. Under most agreements, foreign nationals who are not foreign nationals or subjects are not eligible. Foreign government employees should read the relevant agreements carefully to determine whether they are eligible for benefits.

Students, apprentices, and internship students are exempt from income tax on remittances received from abroad for tuition and living expenses under some income tax treaties. In addition, under some treaties, scholarships and grants, and limited compensation received by students, apprentices, and interns are exempt from income tax. If you entered the United States as a non-tax resident who has become a tax resident, the exemption from income tax treaties still applies.
Most treaties provide for exemptions for gains from the sale or exchange of personal property. Generally, gains from the sale or exchange of real property located in the United States are taxable.
The tax law defines the rights of residents to the benefits of tax agreements in the following cases:

Residents of the United States who are not lawful permanent residents of the United States (e.g., under the United States-China Agreement); other residents of the United States who are lawful permanent residents of the United States (e.g., under the United States-China Agreement); If you receive social security benefits from Canada or Germany, include them in the Social Security Worksheet in the instructions for Form 1040 in line 1 to determine the amount of tax due on Form 1040 or on Form 1040-SR, line 6b. You do not have to file Form 8833 for these benefits.

Generally, you must be a non-tax resident defined foreign student, apprentice, intern, teacher, professor, or researcher to qualify for the tax treaty exemption for overseas remittances, scholarships, grants, and research grants required to study and sustain life in the United States, as well as for wages or other personal service remuneration. However, if you entered the United States as a non-tax resident but you are now a tax resident for U.S. tax purposes, the treaty exemption will continue to apply in the following circumstances: The reservation clause of the tax treaty (see paragraph above) provides for an exceptional interpretation, and you also qualify for the treaty exemption, including any time limitation on the application for the treaty exemption, see paragraph below. This is true even if you choose to file a consolidated tax return as defined in section 1 of the tax treaty, as well as the W-9 form. You may also be able to file a tax return with the tax treaty if you meet the requirements for the reservation clause of the treaty, and you have the ability to file a tax return.

In some cases, you may not be required to file income on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR because the agreement exempts the income from U.S. taxation. However, if the income has been filed as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099 or other information on a tax return, you should file it on the corresponding line of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For example, the amount reported in the first box of Form W-2, line 1a) report the amount of the benefit agreement in brackets in the attached Form 1041, line 8z). Enter Exempt income, the name of the state/territory agreement, and the agreement providing the exemption.

If you apply for any of the benefits of the Agreement that are in excess of or in modification of the IRS regulations and your tax is (or may be) reduced by applying for these benefits, you must attach a completed Form 8833 to your tax return. See below for exceptions to the requirement that you do not file Form 8833.

You do not have to file Form 8833 in any of the following circumstances: 1. you request a tax deduction under the agreement to reduce the total income of the FDAP (usually at the rate of 30%). 2. you request a reduction or modification of the income of non-independent individual service income, pension, annuity, social security and other public pension or artist, athlete, student, intern or teacher. This includes taxable scholarships and grants. 3. you request a reduction or modification of income tax under international security agreements or diplomatic or consular agreements. 4. you are a beneficiary of a partnership or trust of your business, i.e. the partnership, trust, or trust is required to disclose information on its tax return. 5. you request a deduction of the total income of the business or project for which it is not in accordance with the agreement. 6. you are receiving tax information for all taxable persons. 6. you are receiving tax benefits based on the following conditions: 1. the company is a member of the US government.
If you need to report your benefits but don't, you will be fined $1,000 for each failure to report.

An international organization is an organization designated by the President of the United States by executive order and entitled to the privileges, exemptions, and immunities provided by the International Organization Exemption Act. The exemptions discussed in this chapter apply only to wages earned in the performance of official services for a foreign government or international organization. The income earned by an individual who qualifies for this exemption from other sources in the United States may be taxed in full or may be treated with preferential treatment under the terms of the applicable tax treaty.

You should first check the exemption provisions under the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations or the Bilateral Consular Convention (if any) to confirm that your salary qualifies for U.S. income tax exemption under these provisions. Generally, if you are a U.S. citizen or tax law definition resident, you are not entitled to the income tax exemption under the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations or the Bilateral Consular Convention. For further information on the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations and the Bilateral Consular Convention, please email the Department of State's Foreign Missions Office at OFMAssistants@state.gov.uk.

If you are not eligible for exemption under the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties or the Bilateral Consular Convention, but are from a country that has a tax treaty with the United States, you should check the tax treaty to see if there is a provision for exemption from U.S. income tax on your salary. If you are a U.S. citizen or a tax resident who works for a foreign government in the United States, your salary is generally not exempt from tax. For more information, see Foreign Government Workers' Compensation and Pensions, published in Publication No. 901.

Foreign government employees who do not qualify for the Vienna Convention on Taxation, the Bilateral Consular Convention, or the Taxation Agreement may be exempt from U.S. income tax on such wages if they meet the following requirements for exemption from taxation of foreign government wages under U.S. tax law. The exemption under the U.S. tax code applies only to current foreign government employees, not to former employees. Pensions received by former employees of foreign governments residing in the United States are not eligible for the exemption discussed here.

You have been issued a State Department certificate (if you have one) that establishes that you qualify for similar services and the equivalent exemption requirements, but do not need to qualify for the U.S. tax law exemption. If you have been issued a certificate, and you have information that you are eligible for the exemption, and that the certificate is currently valid and applicable to you, please email the State Department's Mission Office at OFMAssistants@state.gov. If you do not have a valid certificate, you must use other written proof to establish that the services you perform are of a similar nature to those provided by U.S. government employees in a foreign country and that your foreign government employer provides an exemption to U.S. employees in their country who provide similar services.

Many agreements establishing international organizations contain a provision that allows you to be exempt from U.S. income tax on your wages. If you are employed in the United States by an international organization, first confirm whether the international agreement of the international organization that establishes your work includes this provision and whether you meet this provision. Usually, these provisions do not exempt the wages of U.S. citizens and tax law definitions of residents.

You are not a U.S. citizen if the international agreement of the international organization that created your job does not contain an exemption and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen but also a citizen of the Republic of the Philippines), you may be exempt from paying your payroll tax under U.S. tax law. However, see the following for specific rules that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. The exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of the international organization, and does not apply to former employees.

If you have signed an exemption under Section 247 (b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (USCIS Form I-508) and retained your lawful permanent resident status (Green Card), you will no longer be eligible for exemption under U.S. tax law as of the date of filing the exemption. If you are a foreign government employee or an international organization with a green card, you must also be able to file for exemption under U.S. tax law with written evidence from USCIS that you have not signed and filed a USCIS Form I-508.

Before leaving the United States, all foreign nationals (except those listed below who do not require a tax exit permit) must obtain a certificate of compliance. This document, also known as a departure permit or exit permit, is part of the income tax form that must be filed before departure. You will receive an exit permit or exit permit after you submit Form 1040-C or Form 2063. These forms are discussed in this chapter. To confirm whether you need an exit permit or exit permit, first read the following paragraphs.
The declaration must be submitted to the Taxpayer Assistance Center (TAC) office of the IRS.

If you are an alien under either of the categories (1) or (2) above and you file a waiver under Section 247 (b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain a departure permit or a departure permit. This is true even if your income is exempt from U.S. taxation under income tax treaties, consular agreements, or international agreements.

Foreign students, industrial interns, and exchange visitors, including their spouses and children, who are entering the United States only on an F-1, F-2, H-3, H-4, J-1, J-2, J-1, or JQ visa and who have not received any other income from the United States during the period of their stay in the United States, except for: a stipend to pay for expenses incurred in studying or training in the United States (such as travel, maintenance, and tuition); the price of any services or lodging associated with such study or training; income from employment authorized by USCIS; or income from deposits not closely related to trade or business in the United States. (See Chapter 3 Income from interest)

Foreign students, including their spouses and children, who are entering the United States on an M-1 or M-2 visa only and who do not receive any other income from U.S. sources while in the United States, except income from work authorized by the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) or income from deposits that are not closely related to U.S. trade or business. (See Chapter 3 Income from Interest).

Certain other aliens who are temporarily in the United States and who, up to and including the tax year or prior tax year of the scheduled departure date, have not received taxable income. If the IRS has reason to believe that an alien received taxable income that would affect the collection of income taxes, the IRS may require that alien obtain an exit permit or an exit permit. Such aliens are: 1. foreign military personnel who are trained, enter the United States Department of Defense sponsored training, and are granted the privilege to leave the United States as soon as possible, and are granted the period of validity of four years, and are exempt from the requirement of military travel; 2. foreign business travelers who are B-1 visa holders or B-1 visa and B-2 visa holders who have not resided in the United States or U.S. territory for more than 90 days in the tax year; 3. foreign tourists who are B-2 visa holders; 4. foreign tourists who are C-1 visa holders who have not resided in the United States or U.S. territory for more than 90 days; or 5. foreign tourists who have not been in the United States for more than 90 days; or have not been in the United States territory for more than 90 days; or have not been in the United States territory for more than 90 days; or have been in the United States territory; or have been in the United States for more than 90 days; or have been in the United States; or have been in the United States; or have been in the United States; or have been in the United States; or have been in any territory; 2. foreign country; or have been in the United States; or have been in the United States; or have been in any country; have been in the United States; have been in the United States; have been; have been in the United States; have been; have been in the United States; have been; have been in the United States; have been in the United States; have been; have been in the United States; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present; have been present;
Foreign residents of Canada or Mexico who commute between Canada and the United States for work and whose wages are subject to U.S. tax withholding.

If you bring documents and documents related to your income and residence in the United States to the TAC office, you will be granted your exit permit or exit permit more quickly. If you are applying for this permit, please carry the following documents. 1. Your passport and alien registration card or visa. 2. Copies of the U.S. income tax returns you have filed for the past 2 years. If you have resided in the United States for less than 2 years, please carry the income tax returns you filed for that period.

Any alien who has not filed a tax return for income tax for any taxable year or has not paid income tax for that year must file a tax return and pay income tax before he or she can be issued a departure permit or a departure permit. A departure permit or a departure permit that is separated from Form 2063 may be used for all departure operations during the current year. However, if the IRS considers that the collection of income tax is affected by the continued departure, it may revoke the departure permit or the departure permit for the continued departure.

If you must obtain an exit permit or an exit permit and you are not eligible to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Generally, all income received or expected to be received by an individual during the tax year up to and including the date of departure must be reported on Form 1040-C and tax must be paid on such income. If you pay any of the due dates shown on Form 1040-C, if you file all tax returns and pay all due taxes for the previous year, you will receive an exit permit or an exit permit. However, the IRS may allow you to provide a bond to cover the payment of taxes instead of paying taxes for certain years.

If you have provided the IRS with information that satisfies the IRS that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure will not affect taxation, you may obtain an exit permit or exit permit by submitting the following documents and filing Form 1040-C without paying the taxes shown above. However, you must file all income tax returns that have not yet been filed as required and pay the taxes due on those returns.

Expatriate spouses who are non-tax residents may not file a joint return. However, if both spouses are tax residents, they may file a joint return on Form 1040-C if: both spouses are reasonably expected to be eligible to file a joint return at the normal end of the tax year for both spouses; and both spouses have the tax year end at the same time.

You must pay all taxes due on the Form 1040-C at the time of filing, unless you file a bond, or the IRS is satisfied that your departure does not affect the collection of income taxes. You must also pay taxes due for the previous year. If the tax calculation on Form 1040-C results in an overpayment, no tax is paid at the time of filing.

Generally, when you file Form 1040-C, you must pay the taxes shown above. However, if you pay all the taxes due for the previous year, you may provide a bond that pays the tax on the bond instead of paying the income tax due on Form 1040-C; or, if the filing deadline is not yet reached, the tax return for the previous year.

Form 1040-C is not an annual return for U.S. income tax. If required by law, you must file it even if you filed Form 1040-C. Chapters 5 and 7 discuss filing your annual return for U.S. income tax. Taxes paid on Form 1040-C are considered a credit on your annual return for the entire tax year.
If you have questions about your taxes, need help with your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, go to IRS.gov for resources that can help you immediately.

After you receive all of your salary and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment compensation statements (in mailed or digital format), or other government payment statements (Form 1099-G), and interest, dividend, and retirement statements from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you can choose from several options to prepare and file your tax returns. You can either prepare your own tax returns, check your eligibility for exempt returns, or hire a tax professional to prepare your tax returns.

You need an IRS Online Account (OLA) to complete the form that requires your signature. You can choose to submit the form online or download a copy for mailing. You will need your file scanned to support your submission. For more information, go to IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms.

Go to IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. Browse the amount you owe and break it down by tax year. View payment plan details or apply for a new payment plan. Make payments or view 5-year payment history and any pending or scheduled payments. View your tax records, including key data from your most recent tax return, and your tax receipts. View digital copies of notices selected by the IRS. Approve or deny authorization requests from tax professionals. View your file address or manage your communication preferences.

Through the online account, you can access information to help you with your tax season. You can get a receipt, view your most recently filed tax return, and get adjusted total receipts. Go to IRS.gov/Account to create or access your online account.
The tool allows your tax professional to submit an authorization request to access your individual IRS Online Taxpayer Account (OLA). For more information, please visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

Direct deposit is the safest and easiest way to get a tax refund. Direct deposit is the electronic method of safely depositing your tax refund directly into your financial account. Direct deposit also helps prevent your checks from being lost, stolen, damaged, or returned to the IRS if they are not delivered. 80% of taxpayers use direct deposit to get their tax refund. If you do not have a bank account, please visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to learn more about where to find banks or credit unions that can open online accounts.

The IRS does not contact taxpayers via email, SMS (including short links), telephone, or social media channels to request or verify personal or financial information. The IRS does not request or verify personal or financial information, including personal identification numbers (PINs) for credit cards, bank or other financial accounts, passwords, or similar information. Refer to IRS.gov/IdentityTheft (the IRS Identity Theft Center web page) for information about taxpayers, tax professionals, and businesses related to identity theft and data security. You can learn what steps you should take if your SSN is lost or stolen or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft.

The IRS cannot issue refunds for tax return applications for low-income family benefits (EICs) or additional child tax credits (ACTCs) until mid-February. The rule applies to all refunds, not just the portions associated with these credit benefits.

U.S. taxes must be remitted to the IRS in U.S. dollars. No digital assets are accepted. Please visit IRS.gov/Payments for more information on how to make payments using any of the following options. Direct payment: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax directly from your checking or savings account without charging you any fees. Debit card, credit card or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment service provider, pay online or by phone.

For more information about your options, go to IRS.gov/Payments. Apply for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) so that you can pay in monthly installments if you can't pay your taxes in full today. Once you complete the online process, you'll be notified immediately if your agreement has been approved. Use the Offer Eligibility Preview to see if you can pay your tax debt in less than the full amount you owe. For more information about the offer, go to IRS.gov/ICO.

IRS.gov/WMAR tracks the status of your amended tax return on Form 1040-X. It takes up to 3 weeks from the date you file your amended tax return to appear in our system, and up to 16 weeks to process the return.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). TAS helps taxpayers resolve issues with the IRS, makes administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or correct problems, and protects taxpayer rights. We work to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and to ensure that you are aware of and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Advocacy Act. We are your representatives at the IRS.

TAS can help you solve problems that you cannot solve with the IRS yourself. Make sure to try to solve your problem through the IRS first, but if that doesn't work, then go to TAS. Our services are free. TAS helps all taxpayers and their representatives, including individuals, businesses, and tax-exempt organizations. You may be eligible for TAS help if your IRS problem is causing financial difficulty, if you have tried but have not been able to solve your problem with the IRS, or if you think the IRS system, process, or procedure is not working properly. To get help with general tax topics, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov. The website can help you solve common tax problems and situations, such as if you have made a mistake on your tax return or received a notification from the IRS.

The Taxpayer Bill of Rights describes the ten basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. For more information about these rights, what they mean to you, and how they apply to specific IRS situations you may encounter, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/Taxpayer-Rights. The TAS is dedicated to protecting the rights of taxpayers and ensuring that the IRS enforces tax laws in a fair and just manner.

The Social Security Administration (SSA) provides a quick, free, and secure W-2 filing option for CPAs, accountants, registered agents, and individuals processing Form W-2 (Wages and Taxes) and Form W-2c (Corrections to Wages and Taxes) online at SSA.gov/employer.

If you are a sole proprietor, partnership, or S corporation, you can view tax information in the IRS records and take further action using your business tax account. For more information, visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount.

Why we invite you to visit IRS.gov/SocialMedia to view the various social media tools the IRS uses to share the latest information about tax changes, fraud alerts, programs, products, and services. Privacy and security are our top priorities at the IRS. We use these tools to share public information with you.

The IRS is committed to serving taxpayers with limited English proficiency (LEP) by providing OPI services. OPI services are a federally funded program that are available at Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TACs), most IRS offices, and every VITA/TCE filing location.

You should first determine whether you are a tax resident or a non-tax resident for income tax purposes. If you are a tax resident and a non-tax resident in the same year, you have dual status. See the section on dual status of foreigners below. See also the section on the definition of a non-tax resident's spouse as a tax resident, and some other special circumstances explained below.
If you are a foreign national (non-U.S. citizen), you are considered a non-resident under the tax law unless you pass one of the two tests:

If you pass the green card test or the actual residency test for the year 2024 (i.e., January 1 to December 31), you are a resident as defined by the U.S. tax code. You may elect to be considered a resident for tax law purposes for part of the year, even if you do not pass either test.

If the United States government issues a final administrative or judicial order of removal or expulsion, your status as a resident is considered to have been revoked. A final order of removal is an order that you may not appeal to a higher court of competent jurisdiction.

If USCIS or a U.S. consular officer makes this determination, your residency will be considered waived when a final waiver is issued. If you are granted leave to appeal to a federal court with jurisdiction, a final waiver will also be required. Under U.S. immigration law, legal permanent residents are required to file their tax returns as are residents, and if they do not file, they may lose their status as permanent residents.

You are required to file Form 8843 by the filing deadline of Form 1040-NR. The deadline for filing is discussed in Chapter 7. If you are required to file Form 8843 and you fail to file Form 8843 in time, you cannot be excluded from the date you reside in the United States as a professional athlete or because you have a medical condition while in the United States. If you can demonstrate by convincing clear evidence that you have taken reasonable steps to understand the filing requirements and have complied with these important steps, you are not eligible for a waiver of your right to receive a waiver.

"Foreign government related person" means an individual who is temporarily residing in the United States (e.g., or an immediate relative of such individual) as a full-time employee of an international organization; as a diplomat; or as a visa holder in full-time diplomatic or consular status as determined by the Secretary of the Treasury of the United States (except for visas granting lawful permanent resident status).

Generally, if you are in the United States as a private employee, servant, or domestic servant of a foreign government or an international organization on an A-3 or G-5 visa, you are not considered a person associated with a foreign government and must count all days you are in the United States for the purpose of the actual residency test.

Foreign employers include U.S. entities that have offices or places of business in foreign countries or U.S. territories. If you are excluded from qualifying as a teacher or trainee on a date in the United States, you must file a completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See the contents of Form 8843 below.

You are not considered a resident even if you pass the actual residency test if you have lived in the United States for less than 183 days in a year; have a tax residence abroad for less than one year; and have a relationship with a foreign country where your tax residence is located that is closer to your relationship with the United States than your relationship with the United States (unless you have a close relationship with two foreign countries, discussed later).

You must attach a fully completed Form 8840 to your income tax return claiming that you have close ties with one or more foreign countries. If you do not file the form, send the form to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file Form 8840 by the filing deadline of Form 1040-NR. If you file on the date discussed in Chapter 7 below. If you fail to file Form 8840 in time, you cannot claim that you have close ties with one or more foreign countries. If you can demonstrate by convincing and clear evidence that you have taken reasonable steps to understand the filing requirements and have taken the important steps required to comply with those requirements, then the above does not apply.

Dual-status residents. The rules given here determine whether you are a tax resident under the tax law, and do not override the definition in the RTA. If you are a dual-status resident taxpayer, you may still apply for the Income Tax Agreement Benefit. Dual-status resident taxpayer means a taxpayer who is simultaneously resident under the tax laws of the United States and another country.

If you are a dual-status taxpayer and you apply for an agreement, you must file a return using Form 1040-NR and the accompanying Form 8833 and calculate your tax as a non-tax resident. Resident dual-status taxpayers are also eligible for assistance from the relevant U.S. agencies. See Tax Procedures 2015-40, 2015-35 I.R.B.236, located at IRS.gov/irb/2015-35_IRB#RP-2015-40, or its updated version. See Chapter 9 Reporting Requested Tax Benefits for more information about agreement benefits.
