You may be a resident of both non-resident and resident in the same tax year. This is usually the year you arrive in or leave the United States. For information on filing a return for a tax year with dual resident status, see Chapter 6 for information on dual resident status.

If you are a resident of the United States for the calendar year in which you reside, but you were not a resident of the United States at any time during the previous calendar year, you are a resident of the United States only for the portion of the calendar year beginning on the date on which you reside. For the portion of the year before that date, you are not a resident under the tax law definition.

If you are married and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or tax resident and the other is a non-tax resident, you may elect to treat your non-tax resident spouse as a tax resident at the end of the tax year. This includes: If you are married and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or tax resident at the end of the tax year, you and your spouse are treated as tax residents for the entire tax year. If you and your spouse are married and one spouse is a non-tax resident at the beginning of the tax year, you and your spouse are treated as tax residents at the end of the tax year, and you and your spouse are treated as tax residents for the entire tax year. You and your spouse are not treated as non-U.S. citizens under any tax treaty.

You usually make the choice when you file your joint return. However, you can make the choice by filing your amended joint return on Form 1040-X. You may also file your amended joint return with Form 1040-X or Form 1040-SR and note the Amended (amended) column at the top of the amended tax return. If you choose to file your amended tax return, you and your spouse must also amend any tax returns you file after the year you made the choice.

If either spouse becomes a U.S. citizen or a tax law resident at any time during any tax year after the tax year in which you made the election, the tax law definition of the choice of resident is suspended for that tax year. If either spouse meets the reporting requirements for the nontax law definition of resident discussed in Chapter 7, this means that each spouse must file a separate tax return for the year in the amount of the nontax law definition of resident.

Once an election is made, the election is valid for all subsequent years unless it is suspended (as explained under the suspension option above) or terminated by one of the following methods: If the election is terminated in one of the following ways, either spouse may not make the election in any subsequent tax year. 1. Withdrawal. 2. Any spouse may withdraw the election for any tax year provided that the election is withdrawn by the end of the tax year for which the tax return is due.

If you are a non-tax resident for the entire tax year and are a resident of the United States or Puerto Rico, you are required to pay tax under the tax law definition of resident, with certain exceptions. For more information, see Chapter 5 of the United States or Puerto Rico Tax Law definition of resident. If you are a non-tax resident for the entire tax year and are not a resident of the United States or Puerto Rico, you are not required to pay tax under the tax law definition of resident.

After you have established your status as a foreigner, you must determine the source of your income. This section helps you to determine the source of the different types of income you may receive in the tax year.

Income of residents, as defined by the Internal Revenue Code, is generally taxed in the same way as income of U.S. citizens. If you are a resident, you must file U.S. income tax returns for all income from interest, dividends, wages, or other services, income from rental property, or income from copyright taxes, and other types of income. You must report these amounts received from sources within or outside the United States.

Non-residents are defined by the tax law as those who are taxed only on income derived from sources within the United States, and on certain income derived from engaging in trade or business in the United States (see Chapter 4). For a general rule for income derived from the United States that applies to most non-residents defined by the tax law, see Table 2-1 . The following discussion covers both the general rule and the exceptions to these rules . Not all income derived from the United States is taxable . See Chapter 3 .

Real estate is property consisting of land and the buildings on it, along with any immovable property of any kind, including land and buildings, and the buildings on it, and the immovable property consisting of any part of it. Real estate is property consisting of land and the buildings on it, along with any part of it; the immovable property comprises all property of any kind; buildings, structures, and objects, whether real or personal, constructed, erected, erected, or any other; land, buildings, property, or buildings; and all things normally erected, erected, or made thereon, or affixed to the land; and the aggregate income from the immovable property, including the income, profit, and expenses of the sale or disposition of the immovable property; and the immovable property comprising all property of any kind, including the immovable property.

Income from the sale of any farm, mine, oil well or gas well, other natural mineral deposits or timber products located in the United States and sold in foreign countries, or from the sale of any farm, mine, oil well or gas well located in foreign countries and sold in the United States, and income from the sale of any such products in foreign countries, a portion of which is derived from the United States. For information on determining that portion of income, see section 1.863-1 (b) of the Regulations.

Personal property is non-real property such as machinery, equipment, or furniture. If you have a taxable residence in the United States, the gain or loss on the sale or exchange of personal property is generally considered to have originated in the United States. If you have no taxable residence in the United States, the gain or loss on the sale or exchange is generally considered to have originated in the United States.

inventory property is personal property held by you in the course of trade or business, or owned by you for sale to the customer. The income from the sale of inventory that you purchase comes from the sale of the property. Usually, this is where ownership of the property passes to the buyer. For example, income from the sale of inventory in the United States is income derived from the United States, whether you bought it in the United States or in another country. You produce inventory property in the United States and sell it outside the United States (and vice versa), and the income from the sale derives from the production of that property. Even if you are not a U.S. resident for tax purposes, this rule applies.

To determine the source of any gain on the sale of depreciated personal property, you must first calculate the portion of the gain that does not exceed the total depreciation adjustment for that property. You allocate that portion of the gain to sources within the United States based on the ratio of the depreciation adjustment to the total depreciation adjustment for that property. The remainder of that portion of the gain is treated as having been derived from sources outside the United States. For this purpose, the U.S. depreciation adjustment is the amount of the gain on the property that allows the basis of the gain to be depreciated when calculating the taxable gain on the property of U.S. origin. However, if the asset is used primarily in the United States during the taxable year, all the gain on the property for that year is treated as a U.S. depreciation adjustment.

Intangible property includes patents, copyrights, proprietary procedures or formulations, reputation, trademarks, trade marks or other similar property. Proceeds from the sale of depreciable or depreciable intangible property, up to the maximum previously allowed depreciation or depreciation deduction, shall be sourced in the same manner as the original deduction. This is the same as the rules of origin for the proceeds from the sale of depreciable property.

Notwithstanding any prior rule, if you have no tax residence in the United States but you have an office or other fixed place of business in the United States, any income from the sale of personal property (including inventory property) shall be treated as income of United States origin if it is income from that office or place of business. However, if your office or other fixed place of business outside the United States is materially involved in the sale of inventory property for use, disposal or consumption outside the United States, this rule does not apply to such sales. If you do not have a tax residence in the United States but you have an office or other fixed place of business outside the United States, the sale of personal property shall be treated as income of United States origin except for inventory property.

The place or manner of payment is not relevant in determining the source of income. An alternative interest payment made to the transferee of a security in a securities lending transaction or a sale and repurchase transaction, the source of which is the same as the source of the interest on the transferred security.

Generally, interest income derived in the United States does not include the following items: 1. interest paid on debt issued by a resident or domestic corporation as defined by the tax code prior to August 10, 2011, if the taxpayer's total income during the 3 years ending in the taxpayer's tax year prior to the payment of interest was at least 80% (0.80): 1. from sources outside the United States; and 2. was due to the active conduct of a trade or business by the individual or corporation in a foreign country or U.S. territory. However, if any of the following applies, the interest will be considered to be interest income derived in the United States: 1. the interest received by the interest is related to a resident or domestic corporation as defined by the tax code; see Section 954 (d) (3) of the Internal Revenue Code regarding the definition of a related individual contribution; 2. the annual provision of the obligation is subject to a substantial revision of the term of the obligation; any extension of the term of the obligation is considered to be substantially modified; 2. interest paid by a resident or domestic corporation to a foreign corporation through a subsidiary of a foreign corporation is a substantial change in the interest paid by the interest on the domestic interest accrued by the domestic corporation through a domestic bank, cooperative, credit union, savings institution, credit union, or other domestic banking institution or savings institution or other institution or association or other institution that is a domestic bank or other institution that is a savings or credit union or financial institution; or financial institution that is a savings institution or credit union or financial institution; or other institution that is a building or other institution that is subject to federal law; 3. interest accrued by a foreign corporation and is subject to a special interest on the domestic loan, but is subject to the supervision of a federal, but not subject to, but is subject to, a special interest on a special purpose of, a special purpose of, a foreign law;

In most cases, dividend income received from domestic companies is considered to be U.S.-sourced income. Dividend income from foreign companies is generally considered to be foreign-sourced income. Exceptions to the second rule are discussed below. Alternative dividend payments paid to the transferee in a securities lending transaction or a sell-back transaction are considered to have the same source of origin as the source of distribution of the transferred securities.

If the taxpayer is a party to the underlying contract, the payment of the dividend-equivalent amount includes the total amount of the dividend that involves U.S.-sourced dividends, and any total amount used to calculate any net amount transferred to or from the taxpayer under the contract. Therefore, the dividend-equivalent payment may be considered received even if the taxpayer has paid the net amount, or has not paid any amount because the net amount is zero. In 2024, if the contract is for a delta one, the NPC or ELI is usually a specific NPC or a specific ELI, respectively.

All wages and any other remuneration received in the performance of services in the United States shall be deemed to have been derived from the United States. The only exceptions to this rule are the employees of foreign persons, organizations, or offices and the crew mentioned above. If you are an employee and receive remuneration for labor or personal services performed in and outside the United States, special rules apply in determining the source of remuneration.

Some companies sell products through multi-level marketing arrangements, to the extent that the upper level distributors who sponsor the lower level distributors are entitled to receive a payment from the company for certain activities of the lower level distributors. Usually, according to the facts, these multi-level marketing companies pay to independent (non-employee) distributors (upper level distributors) based on the sales or purchases of the people they sponsor (lower level distributors), constituting income for the performance of personal services in terms of recruitment, training, and support of lower level distributors. The source of this income is generally determined by the location of the services provided by the upper level distributors, and according to the facts, it can be considered as a multi-year remuneration, where the source of the income can be determined within the period to which the remuneration is attributed.

If you are self-employed, determine the source of your remuneration for your self-employed work or personal services on the basis of the facts and circumstances that most accurately reflect your particular case. In many cases, the following distribution is required according to the facts and circumstances, depending on the time.

The source of multi-year remuneration is generally determined on the basis of the time period to which it should be attributed. Multi-year remuneration is remuneration that is included in your income for 1 tax year but can be attributed for more than 2 tax years. You determine the period to which the remuneration is attributed based on the facts and circumstances of your case. For example, the amount of remuneration that relates to a specific period of time that includes several calendar years can be attributed to the entire multi-year period.
The amount of the additional benefits must be reasonable and you must prove them with sufficient documentation or evidence.

If you are not employed, you are entitled to a reduced rate of pay for your work.The benefits listed above, except for tax refunds and hazardous work or hard labor, are based on your primary place of work.Your primary place of work is usually where you spend the most time working.This may be your office, factory, store, workshop, or other location.If you do not spend the majority of your time working, your primary place of work is where your work is centered, such as your reported workplace or other locations where you need to set your work as a base (a "base").If you have more than one job at any given time, your specific location is analyzed.The most important factors to consider are: the total time you spend in each location, the amount of work you do in each location, and the amount of money you earn in each location.

The source of the education allowance for your dependent child's education depends on your main place of work. The education allowance includes only the following payments for education in primary and secondary schools: tuition fees, fees, academic counselling, special needs services, books, supplies and other equipment for students with special needs.

The source of local transportation allowance depends on the location of your main place of work. Your local transportation allowance is the amount you or your spouse or dependent person receives as compensation for local transportation at your main place of work. The amount of local transportation allowance is limited to the actual expenditure on local transportation and the fair rental value of the employer-provided vehicles that are primarily used by you, your spouse or dependent person for local transportation.

The source of the transfer fee is usually based on the location of your new main place of work. However, if you provide sufficient evidence to prove that the source is more appropriate according to the facts and circumstances of your case, you will determine the source based on the previous main place of work. Sufficient evidence usually requires an agreement between you and your employer, or a written statement of company policy, which was translated into written form before the transfer and was signed or prepared in order to induce you or other employees to move to another country.

If you are an employee, you may determine your source of compensation on the basis of an alternative basis if you demonstrate to the IRS that the alternative basis is more appropriate in determining your source of compensation based on the facts and circumstances of your case. If you use an alternative basis, you must keep and have a verifiable written record of why the alternative basis is more appropriate in determining your source of compensation. And, if all of your sources of compensation total more than $250,000, check the box that says Yes, see Appendix I, Form 1040-NR, line K, two questions and a written statement that will accompany your tax return that states all of the following: 1.

Transportation revenue is income from the use of a ship or aircraft or the provision of services directly related to the use of any ship or aircraft. This is true regardless of whether the ship or aircraft is owned, leased or leased. Ship or aircraft cabins include any assemblies related to the ship or aircraft. All transportation revenue beginning and ending in the United States is considered to be from the United States. If transportation begins or ends in the United States, 50% of the transportation revenue is considered to be from the United States.

Scholarships, research grants, fellowships, awards, and prizes are generally awarded based on the recipient's residence, regardless of who actually pays the funds. However, see below for activities conducted outside the United States. For example, payments made by residents or domestic companies defined by U.S. non-corporate tax law for research or study in the United States are from the United States. Similar payments from foreign governments or foreign companies are considered foreign-sourced payments, even if those payments are made through U.S. agents.

Non-taxable persons are defined as persons who are not residents of the United States and who receive scholarships, research grants, targeted grants, or awards for achievement for activities that they have or will undertake outside the United States. This rule does not apply to amounts paid as salaries or other services. See Personal Services for applicable rules of origin.

If you receive a pension from a domestic trust fund for services rendered in the United States and abroad, part of the pension payment comes from the United States. This part is attributed to the income of the pension plan and the employer's expenditure for services rendered in the United States. The above provisions apply regardless of whether the distribution is made on the basis of qualified or non-qualified stock dividends, pensions, profit sharing or annuity plans (whether or not there are funds). If you provide services as a U.S. employee, you may receive a distribution from a U.S. government program (such as the Public Employee Retirement System), which is considered a qualified pension plan.

If you are required to file a federal income tax return, you may be entitled to certain special disaster-related rules governing the use of your retirement fund. For more information, see Publication No. 590-B. You may also visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

The special rule provides tax incentives for the distribution and reimbursement of certain retirement plans (including IRAs) to taxpayers who have suffered economic losses as a result of certain major disasters. For information on the distribution and reimbursement of qualified disaster plans, see Form 8915-F, Distribution and Reimbursement of Qualified Disaster Plan Retirement Plans, and its notes.

Your U.S.-sourced income includes rental and franchising income earned during the taxable year from property located in the United States or any interest in that property. U.S.-sourced income also includes rental or franchising income earned in the United States for the use or enjoyment of an intangible property (such as patents, copyrights, confidential procedures and formulations, trademarks, trademarks, franchises, and similar property) in the United States.
In these cases, you and your spouse must report joint income, as explained below.

The income earned by the spouse, excluding the allowable share of the income from trade or business and the income from the partnership, is treated as income of the spouse whose services generate income. The spouse must declare all income on his or her own tax return.

Income from a trade or business, excluding the allowable share of the partners' joint income, is treated as income of the spouse who carries on the trade or business. The spouse must declare all income on his or her own tax return.
The distributable share of the partnership's income (or loss) is treated as the partnership's income (or loss). The partnership must report all income on its separate tax return.

Income from the separate property of a spouse (as well as unearned income, trade or business income, income from joint distributable shares) is treated as income of that spouse. The spouse must file all income on his or her separate tax return. Use the appropriate common property laws to determine what is separate property.
All other joint income shall be treated in accordance with the applicable laws on joint property.

If the tax law defines a resident and non-resident as a resident, and if certain conditions are met, a deduction may be made from the total income. The total income deduction is generally the income you receive that is not included in your U.S. income and is not subject to U.S. law. This chapter covers some of the more common deductions that allow the tax law to define a resident and non-resident as a resident.
The tax law defines the following items that residents can deduct from their total income:

You are eligible for a deduction if you have resided in a foreign country for at least 330 full days during any 12 consecutive months and earned income in a foreign country. Except for the deduction of $126,500 in 2024, you may deduct or deduct certain foreign housing amounts. You are also eligible for a deduction if you are a resident of a foreign country and a citizen or national of a country with an income tax treaty with the United States.
The non-tax law defines that residents can deduct the following items from their total income:

Interest income not related to commerce or business in the United States shall not be included in the income of a person who receives interest from: deposits made to bank personnel (including certificates of deposit); deposits or withdrawals from accounts held by mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, domestic building and loan associations, and other savings institutions chartered and supervised by a federal or state law as savings and loans or similar associations, if interest paid or credited to the lender may be deducted by the association; and amounts of interest held and paid by an insurance company under an agreement.

Interest on bonds issued by states or political subdivisions, the District of Columbia, or U.S. territories is generally not included in income. However, interest on certain private activity bonds, arbitrage bonds, and certain unlisted bonds is included in income.

Interest and original issue discount (OID) eligible for portfolio interest are not subject to withholding tax under Articles 3, 1441 to 1443 of the [Central Government Tax Code]. However, if such interest is a deductible payment and no deduction under Articles 4, 1471 to 1474 of the [Central Government Tax Code] exists, such interest is subject to withholding tax. For more information, see the discussion on interest on portfolio investments subject to withholding tax under the Specific Income Tax Deduction, which is available in Publication No. 515. Interest on bonds issued after July 18, 1984 must be paid for the year in which interest is eligible for withholding tax and otherwise payable. For bonds issued after March 18, 2013, the name of the investment portfolio is no longer included in the interest-free bond, and interest is not payable on bonds issued before March 19, 2013, including certain bonds and bonds that are not subject to the registration requirement.

A bond that is considered to be in the form of a note is not considered to be a note at a particular time if it can be converted at any time in the future into a note in the form of a note. For information on whether a bond is considered to be in the form of a note, see the discussion of interest on a portfolio under the specific income withholding tax under the withholding tax under the withholding tax, which is published in Issue No. 515.
For unnamed bonds that are eligible for portfolio interest, no documentation is required. However, in some cases, you will need documentation for the 1099 report and supporting withholding tax.

Payments to certain persons and/or interest payments are not eligible for portfolio interest. You must deduct such payments at the statutory tax rate, unless other exceptions apply (e.g. the provisions of the Agreement).

Interest on a portfolio does not include or is not dividend; or dividend is any of the following: 1. Interest determined by reference to any income, sales or other cash flows of the debtor or related person; income or profits of the debtor or related person; any change in the value of any property of the debtor or related person; or any dividend, joint venture capital or similar payment made by the debtor or related person; see section 871 (h) (4) (C) for exceptions; 2. Any other type of interest or dividend as prescribed by the Minister of Finance in the regulations;

Persons who are:  Family members, including but not limited to siblings, half-siblings, half-sisters, half-brothers, half-sisters, spouses, ancestors, parents, grandparents, etc., and direct descendants, children, grandchildren, etc.;  Persons who are parties to any arrangement to avoid or benefit from the interest rule;  Certain companies, joint ventures, and other entities;  For details, see Chapter 2 of the Indemnifiable Losses in Publication No. 544.

or interest excluding interest paid or accrued on or after April 7, 1993, in respect of any periodic debt issued on or after that date, under a written binding contract in effect on or after that date, for all time prior to the issuance of the debt.
The following dividends are exempt from taxation:

You are exempt from 30% tax on dividends received from foreign sources in the United States. See Exceptions. This is contained in Dividend, see Chapter 2 How to Calculate the Amount of Dividend Received in the United States.

You will not be charged 30% tax on interest-related dividends received from a U.S. based mutual fund or other regulated investment company (RIC). The mutual fund will specify in writing which dividends are interest-related dividends.

You are not taxed at 30% on certain short-term capital gains dividends received from a source in the United States, such as a mutual fund or other regulated investment company (RIC). The mutual fund will designate in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains dividends.
If you receive payments from a foreign employer, your U.S.-sourced income is exempt from U.S. taxation if you meet one of the following conditions:

If you do not meet these three conditions, your income from performing personal services in the United States is U.S.-sourced income and is taxable under the rules of Chapter 4. If you pay more than $3,000 for these services, all of your income is from trade or business income in the United States. If you are determined to have earned more than $3,000 in wages, excluding any advance or refund of business travel expenses you received from your employer, you must and do explain these expenses to your employer. If the advance or refund exceeds your expenses, the excess will be included in your wages for such services. A sundial is your calendar for any period of time you were in the United States.

A non-U.S. citizen alien is a member of the crew of a foreign ship (such as a large ship or small craft) engaged in transportation between the United States and a foreign country or U.S. territory. The person is temporarily resident in the United States and the remuneration for the services rendered is not income of the United States and is exempt from U.S. taxation. This exemption does not apply to remuneration for services rendered on foreign aircraft.

The tax law defines non-resident and exchange students as persons residing in the United States on an F, J, M, Q, or Q visa and may deduct from gross income wages received from foreign employers. This group includes actual students, scholars, students, faculty, professors, research assistants, experts, and exchange students or similar persons who are experts in a field of professional knowledge or skill. If the alien's spouse and minor children come to the United States with the alien or later with the alien, the group also includes the spouse and minor children.
Foreign employer's income excludes foreign government revenues. Wages received from foreign governments that are exempt from U.S. income tax are discussed in Chapter 10.
If you are not sure whether the pension is from a qualified pension plan or a qualified trust, ask the payer.

Any type of income exempt from U.S. taxation under the U.S. Agreement on Income Taxation as a party is deducted from your total income. However, only income subject to taxation under the Agreement is included in your total income. See Chapter 9.

You may deduct from your gross income any winnings that are legally wagered in a single-stakes lottery that originated outside the United States and that are associated with a horse or dog race in the United States.

If you sell your main home, you may deduct up to $250,000 from the sale of the home. If you are married and file a joint return, you may deduct up to $500,000. For information on the deduction, see Publication No. 523.

If you are a degree candidate, you may deduct from your income some or all of the amount received as a qualifying scholarship. The rules discussed here apply to tax law definition residents and non-tax law definition residents alike. If a non-tax law definition resident receives a grant from a non-U.S. source, the grant is exempt from U.S. tax. See Chapter 2 Scholarships, Grants, Awards, and Prizes to determine whether the grant is from the United States.

However, in order for these expenses to be qualified as education expenses, the scholarship or grant provisions may not require that the scholarship or grant be used for other purposes, such as accommodation, or provide that it cannot be used for tuition or course-related expenses.
This is true even if the fees must be paid to the institution as a condition of admission or attendance. Scholarships or grants used to pay for these fees are not taxable.
The amount of the scholarship is tax-deductible for any non-qualifying fees, even if the fees are fees that must be paid to the institution as a condition of admission or attendance.

You cannot deduct from your income any scholarship, grant, or tuition deduction or any part of the payment for past, present, or future teaching, research, or other services. This is true even if all degree candidates are required to perform these services as a condition of obtaining a degree.

The tax law defines residents and non-residents differently. Residents are taxed in the same manner as U.S. citizens. Residents are taxed according to the source of income and whether their income is closely related to U.S. trade or business. The following discussion will help you determine whether the income you receive in a taxable year is closely related to U.S. trade or business and how it is taxed.

A resident of the United States is a person who is ordinarily resident in the United States and pays taxes on his or her income. This means that his or her worldwide income is taxed in the United States and must be reported on a U.S. tax return. A resident's income is taxed at the progressive tax rate applicable to U.S. citizens.

The difference between the two is that income from closely related persons is taxed at progressive rates after allowable deductions. These rates apply to U.S. citizens and residents alike. Income from non-closely related persons is taxed at 30% (or the lower treaty rate).

Generally, you must be engaged in a particular industry or business in a taxable year in order to consider the income received in that year as income closely related to that industry or business. Whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States depends on the nature of your activity. The following discussion will help you determine whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States.

If you perform personal services in the United States at any time during the taxable year, you are generally considered to be engaged in a trade or business in the United States. Certain payments by foreign employers to non-tax residents are not included in total income. For more information, see Services performed for foreign employers in Chapter 3.

If you are a nonimmigrant on an F, J, M, N, or Q visa and are temporarily residing in the United States and are not otherwise engaged in a trade or business, you are considered to be engaged in a trade or business in the United States if you derive taxable income from a scholarship or grant referred to in section 1441 (b). Any scholarship or research grant that is derived as income from the United States is taxed as closely related to the trade or business in the United States.

If you are a member of a partnership and you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States at any time during the taxable year, you are considered to be engaged in a trade or business in the United States.
If you are a beneficiary of a real estate trust that is engaged in a trade or business in the United States, you are considered to be engaged in the same trade or business.

If your sole business activity in the United States is to transact in stocks, securities, or commodities (including hedging transactions) through a resident broker or other agent as defined by the tax law, you are not engaged in a trade or business in the United States. For stock or securities transactions, the foregoing applies to any non-resident, as defined by the tax law, including stock and securities dealers or brokers. For commodities transactions, the foregoing applies to commodities that are normally traded on an organized commodities exchange, as well as transactions that are normally conducted on that exchange. If you have a U.S. office or other fixed place of business at any time during the taxable year and you transact in stocks, securities, or commodities through that office or that venue, or under the direction of that office or that venue, this discussion does not apply.

If trading in stocks, securities, or commodities for your own benefit is your only activity in the United States, you are not engaged in a trade or business in the United States. The above provisions apply even if the trade was made while you were in the United States or by your employee or agent or other agent. If you are a trader in stocks, securities, or commodities, the above provisions do not apply to a trade or business for your own benefit. However, this does not necessarily mean that you are considered to be engaged in a trade or business in the United States as a trader.

If you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States, all income, gains, or losses you derive from sources within the United States during the taxable year (except certain investment income) are treated as closely related income. The above provisions apply regardless of whether there is any relationship between the income during the taxable year and the trade or business in the United States. The two tests described below, called investment income, determine whether certain investment income (such as interest, dividends, and royalties) is considered closely related to the business. Under certain limited circumstances, certain categories of foreign-sourced income may be considered closely related to trade or business in the United States. For a discussion of these rules, see Foreign income.

Use the two tests described below to determine whether income from a U.S. source that falls into one of the three categories above and is received in a taxable year is closely related to your U.S. trade or business. If the test indicates that the income is closely related, you must include it with your other closely related income. If the income is not closely related, include it with all other income discussed in this chapter with a 30% tax rate.
In this test, income is considered highly correlated if the U.S. trade or business practices are important factors in generating income.

Personal service income includes wages, salaries, commissions, fees, daily allowances, employee benefits, and bonuses. This income may be paid to you in the form of cash, services, or property. If you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States only because you are engaged in a personal service in the taxable year in which you are engaged in the trade or business, the income and gains from the sale or exchange of capital gains and losses are generally not closely related to your trade or business. However, if you hold personal property or services that are directly related to your trade or business, the income or loss is usually closely related to the economic gain or loss of the business.

If you have rendered personal services in the United States after 1986 and in subsequent taxable years, when you defined non-tax resident status, you received pension or retirement distributions that were part of those services, such distributions are closely related to the income that is partly attributed to the distributions. This is the case regardless of whether you were engaged in a trade or business in the United States in the year in which you received the pension or retirement distributions.

A fixed place of business is a place, place, building, or other similar facility where you do business or trade. A regularly scheduled transportation is a ship or aircraft that regularly and frequently flies between the same place on a voyage or flight to or from the United States, and is operated under the same operating conditions. A fixed place of business is a place where goods are taken for transportation to or from the United States, and is not used for the purpose of transportation.

U.S.-sourced profit or loss generated by operating a business in the United States that is closely related to the business in the United States. For example, profit from the sale of inventory property in the United States or purchased in a foreign country in the United States is closely related to the business income. A share of the profit or loss of a joint venture that engages in the business in the United States is also closely related to the business.

Gains and losses from the sale or exchange of U.S. real property rights (whether or not they are capital assets) are taxable as if you were engaged in a trade or transaction in the United States. You must treat such gains or losses as closely related to the trade or business.

A U.S. real estate interest does not include a company's stock regularly traded on a large securities market unless you own more than 5% of the fair market value of that company's stock (or, in the case of REITs, more than 10% of its stock). A foreign company with a U.S. real estate interest is generally not a U.S. real estate interest unless the company chooses to be treated as a domestic company.

In most cases, any distribution made by QIE to a non-tax resident, foreign corporation, or other QIE, if it is a proceeds of sale or exchange of U.S. real property interest, is deemed to be a proceeds of sale or exchange of U.S. real property interest recognized by that non-tax resident, foreign corporation, or other QIE. Certain exceptions apply to the QIE's rules of transparency. If a shareholder owns less than 5% of the stock on the date of distribution of QIE to a stock regularly traded on a U.S.-sized securities market, within 1 year, the distribution is not considered to be a proceeds of sale or exchange of U.S. real property interest. If the shareholder is an eligible shareholder, the distribution made by the REIT is not generally considered to be a proceeds of sale or exchange of U.S. real property rights. You may be entitled to receive interest or dividends on the sale of U.S. real property as a proceeds of sale of fixed income.

Disposal payments for REIT shares held by qualifying shareholders directly (or indirectly through more than one joint venture) are not considered U.S. real estate interests. See § 897 (k) (2) through (4) for more information.

In determining whether a QIE is a domestic holding entity, the following rules apply: 1. a person who holds less than 5% of any class of QIE shares, if the shares are regularly traded on a U.S. stock market throughout the test period, is deemed to be a U.S. person, unless QIE actually knows that the person is not a U.S. person; 2. any shares of a QIE held by another QIE, are deemed to be held by a foreign person, if: 1. any class of shares of that other QIE are regularly traded on a U.S. stock market; or 2. that other QIE holds a RIC for the issuance of certain redeemable securities; 3. that any other QIE holds QIE shares not described above, is deemed to be held by a U.S. person, as determined by the proportion of QIE shares held by the U.S. person.

If you complete the above, you are considered to have received a dividend from the sale or exchange of an interest in U.S. real property in an amount equal to the amount of the distribution that would have been considered as such a dividend. This provision also applies to any alternative dividend payment. The following circumstances do not qualify as applicable fictitious sales transactions: you actually receive a distribution from a domestic holding QIE in connection with an interest disposed of or acquired in the transaction; or you dispose of any class of shares of QIE regularly traded on a securities market of U.S. size, provided that you do not hold more than 5% of that class of shares for a year as of the date of the distribution.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner of a U.S. or foreign joint venture engaged in (or deemed to be engaged in) a trade or business in the United States, and you directly or indirectly dispose of the interest, the gain or loss of the interest of the joint venture may affect your federal tax liability. Pursuant to Section 864 (c) (8), your sale, exchange or other disposition of the gain or loss of the interest of the joint venture is deemed to be closely related to the trade or business in the United States. However, the transfer of the amount of the gain or loss of the interest of the joint venture is limited to the amount of the gain or loss of the interest of the joint venture if the distribution of your share of the gain or loss of the interest of the joint venture occurs on the date the disposition of the joint venture permits the sale of all of its assets at a public market price. Income from foreign sources that is equivalent to any of the above is considered to be income that is closely related to U.S. trade or business. For example, if a foreign national earns income in the form of interest and dividend equivalent income from foreign sources in the United States through active banking, financial or similar business, such income is considered to be income that is closely related to the United States.

Income received during the tax year that is closely related to your trade or business in the United States is taxed at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and residents, after deduction of allowable deductions. Generally, you can receive closely related income only during the tax year in which you are a non-tax resident who is engaged in a trade or business in the United States. However, if you receive payments in a tax year in which you are not engaged in a trade or business in the United States through the sale or exchange of property, the performance of services, or any other transaction, but these payments are considered closely related income when the transaction occurs or the year in which you perform the services, they are considered closely related income in the tax year in which you receive the payments.
You can choose to treat all income from real estate as income.
The 30% (or lower) tax rate applies to certain items of income or benefits from U.S. sources, but only if the items are closely related to your U.S. trade or business.

The 30% (or lower) tax rate applies to the total amount of income, profits, or income derived from fixed, determinable, annual, or periodic FDAP in the United States. When the amount of income is paid in advance, it is fixed income. When the amount to be paid is calculated, it is income. If the income is paid regularly, it is periodic.

Usually, if the total income earned from gambling in the United States is not closely related to the commerce or business of the United States, and is not tax-deductible under the treaty, then non-tax law defines a resident as paying 30% of that income in tax. However, in the United States, non-tax law defines non-business gambling income earned by residents by playing 21 points, Baccarat, craps, roulette or Big 6 games. Net gambling income earned in the United States that is closely related to American commerce or business is taxed to non-tax law defines residents at progressive tax rates. Under some tax treaties, this income is tax-deductible.

Non-taxable persons are defined as those who are eligible for a federal government-funded pension plan that includes a U.S. Social Security benefit equal to 85% of their income from a fixed, determinable, annual or periodic (FDAP) income sourced in the United States. Social Security benefits include monthly retirement, survivor and disability benefits. Under some tax treaties, this income is exempt from taxation. See Table 1 in the Tax Treaty Tables at IRS.gov/TreatyTables for a list of tax treaties under which Social Security benefits are exempt from U.S. taxation. For more information, see Item 915 of the IRS Code.

If you choose to treat the income as closely related to trade or business in the United States, the income in paragraph (1) is not subject to the 30% (or lower) tax rate. See below for income from real estate.

If you are not located in the United States and you have not established a taxable year for a prior period, your taxable year will be a calendar year under the 183-day rule. In addition, you must file a tax return in the calendar year. If you reside in the United States for less than 183 days in the taxable year, capital gains (except those listed above) are exempt from taxation unless they are closely related to your trade or transactions in the United States during the taxable year.

The loss of income from the sale or exchange of capital assets closely related to trade or business in the United States, as reported on Schedule NEC (Form 1040-NR). The loss of income from the sale or exchange of capital assets (including real estate) closely related to trade or business in the United States, as reported on Schedule D (Form 1040) or Form 4797, or both.

If you receive income from real estate located in the United States and you own or have an interest in that real estate and hold it for income, you may elect to have all income from that property as income closely related to a trade or business in the United States. This option applies to all income from real estate located in the United States and held for income, and all income from any such property interest. This includes rental royalties collected from mines, oil and gas wells, or other natural resources. It also includes income from the sale or exchange of timber, coal, or domestic iron ore that retains an economic interest.

You may file Form 1040-X for the year you made the election and for subsequent tax years, and cancel the election without the IRS approval. You must file Form 1040-X within 3 years of the date of your tax return, or 2 years after the date of tax payment, whichever is later.

This 4% tax is applicable to your total transportation income of U.S. origin. If the transportation begins or ends in the U.S., this transportation income is included only as transportation income of U.S. origin. For transportation income from personal services, the transportation must be between the U.S. and U.S. territories. For personal services defined by the tax law as non-resident, this provision applies only to income from or related to aircraft.

Under this special rule, unless you pay the higher tax rate provided for in section 871 (i.e., the rule that generally applies to income defined as a non-tax resident, as discussed above) after taking into account the preferences of the applicable agreement, you shall pay your tax on your U.S.-origin gross income at the net progressive rate applicable to individuals for the period that applies to your non-tax resident definition. For information on how the special tax is calculated, see the following section on the withholding tax.

If you are required to file this tax in any year during which you were designated as a non-tax resident, you must file Form 1040-NR for that year. The tax return expires on the date (including the extension) before you file your U.S. income tax return for the year in which you became a tax resident again. If you filed your tax return for that period, you must file a modified return.

The following section describes the rules for renunciation of citizenship under Section 877A for persons who renounced their citizenship on or after June 17, 2008. See below for departures after June 16, 2008. If you renounced your citizenship before June 17, 2008, see the Forms for renunciation of citizenship after June 3, 2004 and June 17, 2008, which are described in Chapter 4 of Publication 519 of 2018 and Form 8854 of 2018. If you renounce your citizenship or terminate your long-term resident status after June 3, 2004 and before June 17, 2008, you will continue to be considered a U.S. taxpayer or resident until you notify the Department of State or the Department of Homeland Security (if applicable) that you have renounced your citizenship and file Form 8854 with the IRS.
Your date of naturalization is the date on which you renounced your U.S. citizenship ("former U.S. citizen") or your long-term residency ("former resident" as defined in the tax code).

You must file the original Form 8854 on the date you renounce your U.S. citizenship or terminate your long-term resident status, even if you are not a qualified renunciant. In addition, you must file Form 8854 annually after you renounce your citizenship if you are a qualified renunciant and you: 1. deferred payment of the day-to-day capital gains tax (see below for deferred payment of the day-to-day capital gains tax), 2. have a qualified deferred compensation plan, or 3. have a non-granted trust benefit.

You are considered to have terminated your long-term resident status on the earliest of the following dates: 1. the date you voluntarily relinquish your lawful permanent resident status by filing Form I-407 with the Department of Homeland Security and with a U.S. consular or immigration officer; 2. the date you receive a final executive order relinquishing your lawful permanent resident status; or, if that order has been appealed, the date of a final court order relating to that executive order; 3. the date you are expelled from the United States by a final executive order under the Immigration and Nationality Act; 4. the date you are considered to have become a resident of the United States and a country with which the United States has a double taxation agreement, in accordance with the provisions of the Agreement, and the date you notify the IRS of your treatment therein; and 4. the date you became a resident of the United States and notified the IRS of your treatment on Form 8833 and Form 8854 (see Section 1 of the Agreement).

You are considered to be a qualifying renunciant if you have renounced your citizenship after the date of your death, and the renouncement rule under Section 877A applies if you meet the following conditions: (1) If you renounce your citizenship or terminate your residency in 2024, your average annual net income taxable income for the five years preceding the date of your renouncement of your citizenship or termination of your residency exceeds $201,000; (2) If you have a net worth of $2 million or more as of the date of your departure or termination of your residency; (3) If you fail to demonstrate on Form 8854 that you have satisfied all of your U.S. federal tax obligations for the five years preceding the date of your renouncement of your citizenship or termination of your residency;

In the year you renounce your citizenship, you will pay income tax on unrealized net gains (or losses) on your property, just as if the property had been sold at its fair market value the day before your renouncement date (taxed at market value). This applies to most types of property rights you held on the date you renounced citizenship or terminated residency. However, see the following exceptions for the renouncement.

After you determine your alien status, the source of your income, and whether and how your income is taxable in the United States, your next step is to calculate your tax. The information in this chapter is not as comprehensive for tax law residents as it is for non-tax law residents. Because the information on tax returns for tax law residents is generally the same as for tax law residents, tax law residents should receive the same publications, forms, and explanations as U.S. citizens. If you are both a tax law resident and a non-tax law resident in the same tax year, see Chapter 6, Discussing Dual Alien Status.

Non-tax law defines a resident as a person who is eligible to claim a deduction for each item of income that the resident is eligible to claim. However, non-tax law defines a resident as a person who has income that is closely related to U.S. trade or business as a person who is eligible to claim a deduction for each item of income that the resident is eligible to claim. Limitations on the amount of deduction for each item of income that you may claim in Schedule A may affect this.

You can apply for the same itemized deduction as a U.S. citizen using Appendix A (Form 1040). For more information, see the instructions for Appendix A (Form 1040). If you do not have itemized deductions, you can apply for standard deductions using your special filing status. For more information, see the Form 1040 description.

If you receive income that is closely related to U.S. trade or business, you may deduct certain itemized deductions. Generally, you may only include deductions and losses that are appropriately allocated and apportioned to income that is closely related to U.S. trade or business. You may not include deductions and/or losses that are associated with tax-exempt income, or deductions and/or losses that are associated with income that is not closely related to U.S. trade or business. However, you may deduct certain charitable donations, accidental losses, and theft losses that are not closely related to your income.
Non-tax resident definition cannot apply for the standard deduction. However, there are special rules for certain non-tax resident definition from India, as described below.

For more information about disaster losses and the conditions under which they are calculated, see Form 4684 (Disclosure) and IRS Disaster Relief. To determine whether you are affected by a major disaster declared by the federal government, visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

A special rule applies to students and apprentices who are eligible for the US-India Income Tax Agreement (ITCA) Section 21 (2) deduction. If you do not claim the itemized deduction, you may claim the standard deduction. Use worksheet 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2024.

If you are a student or business apprentice who is eligible for benefits under Section 21 (2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Act and is affected by certain major disasters declared by the federal government in 2024 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/Disasters), you may elect to increase your standard deduction through any qualifying disaster-related personal injury loss on your 2024 tax return. Use Form 5-1, to calculate your standard deduction for 2024. See Form 4684 and its conditions for more information about the disaster-related personal injury tax benefits.

If your income is closely related to your trade or business in the United States, you may deduct state and local income taxes on that income. Your deduction is limited to a combined total of $10,000 (or $5,000 if you are married and filed separately). If you receive a tax refund or refund in 2024 for taxes you paid in the previous year, you may not deduct that amount from your deduction.

You may deduct your charitable contributions or donations to qualifying organizations, subject to certain restrictions. Qualifying organizations include organizations that are religious, charitable, educational, scientific, or literary in nature or dedicated to the prevention of child or animal abuse. Certain organizations that promote national or international amateur sports competitions are also qualifying organizations. For more information about charitable contributions deductions, see the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations in the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations section of the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations, which is found in the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations section of the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations, which is found in the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations section of the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations, which is found in the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations, which is found in the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations, and which is found in the Exclusion for U.S. charitable organizations.

Donations made directly to an international organization are not deductible. However, donations to a U.S. organization that are controlled by a U.S. organization that transfers funds to a foreign charitable organization, or donations to a U.S. organization that is only an administrative division of a U.S. organization, may be deductible. You may be eligible for a deduction for donations to a foreign charitable organization under a limited number of income tax treaties.

You may deduct accidental loss and theft on your tax return. If the non-business accidental loss is caused by a federally declared disaster, you may deduct only such loss. If your accidental loss or theft is caused by a federally declared disaster, you may deduct your loss even if your property is not related to U.S. trade or business. The property may be personal property used or acquired by a person not related to U.S. trade or business. The property must be located in the United States at the time of the accidental accident or theft. The loss may be deducted only in the year in which the theft was discovered.
For details, see the Explanatory Notes to the CFR, Appendix A, Form 1040-NR, line 7, for a list of item-by-item deductions. See also Publication 529.

You may claim a credit for income tax on income from foreign sources that you have paid or owe to a foreign country, subject to certain restrictions. You cannot claim a credit for income from non-foreign sources that you have paid or owed.

You can get the above credit if you have a dependent person who pays for the care of your dependent child under 13 years of age or if your disability is taken care of by a dependent person or a disabled spouse so that you can work or find work. For more information, see Form 2441 and Publication No. 503.

If you are dependent on a dependent person, spouse, or dependent child for the cost of a qualifying education, you are eligible for these credits. There are two types of education credits: the American Opportunity Credit and the Lifelong Learning Credit.

If you make a qualifying contribution to an employer-sponsored retirement plan or an individual retirement arrangement (IRA) in 2024, you may be eligible for this credit (also known as the Saver's Credit). Use Form 8880 and its instructions to calculate the credit. For more information on the credit requirements, see Publication No. 590-A.

Adopted children are always considered your own children. Adopted children include children who have been legally placed for you to legally adopt. If you do not have an SSN or ITIN on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including deferred return), you cannot claim the child tax credit on your original or modified 2024 tax return. If your child does not have a valid employment SSN issued before the 2024 tax return due date (including deferred return), you cannot claim the child tax credit for this child, but you can claim the child tax credit for this child from other dependents.

The dependent child allowance is for children of dependent parents who: are not eligible for the child tax credit for the dependent parent. The dependent parent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national or tax resident, and must have an SSN, ITIN, or an adopted taxpayer identification number (ATIN) issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date. See Appendix 8812 (Form 1040) and its notes for more information.

EIC or Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) is a benefit for low- and middle-income working people. To qualify for EIC, you must have earned income from working for someone else or running or owning a business or farm, and meet the basic rules. In addition, you must meet the additional rules for non-qualified child workers, or have children who meet all the rules for qualified children. The EIC deducts the amount of tax you owe and may refund the tax to you. For more information, please refer to IRS.gov/EIC. If you and your spouse (if you file jointly) do not have an SSN on your original or modified 2024 tax return, you cannot apply for EIC assistance. If your child does not have a medical insurance card on your original or modified 2024 tax return, or if your spouse is a permanent resident, you may be eligible for EIC benefits, or if your spouse is a U.S. citizen, you may be eligible for a medical card that is issued before the EIC is issued, or your child may not qualify for a medical benefit, such as a valid EITC card, or a qualified permanent resident's tax return. If your spouse is a U.S. citizen, you may be eligible for EIC assistance, and therefore, you may file a valid SIC card, or a child's insurance card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or other, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social Security Card, or a Social
You can apply for the same tax credit as a resident. You can also claim certain taxes that you have paid, are considered to have paid or have been deducted from your income.
You can apply for a deduction from your income if you receive income that is closely related to your income.

If you do not have foreign-sourced income that is closely related to U.S. trade or business, you cannot claim a tax credit. If a foreign or U.S. territory levies a tax on your U.S.-sourced income only because you are a foreign or U.S. territory citizen or resident, you cannot claim any credit for that tax. If you claim a foreign tax credit, you generally do not have to attach Form 1116 to your tax return.

If you have a paying spouse who cares for your eligible child under the age of 13, or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse cares for you so that you can work or find work, you are eligible for the above deduction. For a definition of these terms, see Publication 503. Married non-tax residents are defined as eligible to apply for the deduction, but only if they choose to file jointly with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse. See How to make a choice, Chapter 1, or if they have certain separated married individual filings. See Joint tax return test, Publication 503. In any tax year, the amount of your child and dependent's alimony cannot exceed the amount you earned in the United States in that tax year.

Adopted children are always considered your own children. Adopted children include children who have been legally placed for you to legally adopt. If you do not have an SSN or ITIN on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including deferred return), you cannot claim a child tax credit on your original or modified tax return. If your child does not have a valid employment SSN issued before the 2024 tax return due date (including deferred return), you cannot claim a child tax credit for this child, but you can apply for a child tax credit for this child from other dependent parents.

A dependent who is not eligible for the Child Tax Credit may still qualify for the Other Dependent Credit. The credit is a nonrefundable tax credit of $500 for each eligible individual. The eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or tax law definition resident. See Form 1040-NR Explanation. To qualify for the Other Dependent Credit, your dependent must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN on or before the due date of your 2024 return (including deferred tax returns). Defined only as a nontax resident of a U.S. citizen; a resident of Canada, Mexico, or South Korea; or a student and business trainee from India who is a resident of India and who is in compliance with an income tax treaty with India, as provided in Section 21 (2) (a) (i) (ii) of the Indian Revenue Code, may qualify for the Other Dependent Tax Credit.

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for the conventional cost of adopting a qualifying child. This amount is allowed for adopting a child with special needs, regardless of whether you qualify for the conventional cost. To apply for the adoption credit, file Form 8839 with your Form 1040-NR. Married non-tax resident may apply for the credit, but only if you choose to file a joint return with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse.

If you are a non-tax resident at any time during the tax year, you generally cannot claim the Low Income Family Benefit. However, if you are married and choose to file a joint return with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse, the non-tax resident spouse is treated as a resident for tax purposes. This content is contained in Chapter 1, and you are eligible for the capital credit. If you and your spouse do not have an SSN on or before the 2024 tax return due date (including the deferred tax return), you cannot apply for the EIC on your original or modified 2024 tax return.

When you are a non-tax resident, any federal income tax withheld from your pay during the taxable year is allowed as payment of your U.S. income tax liability for the same year. You may claim a withholding of income tax regardless of whether you engaged in a trade or business in the United States during the year, and regardless of whether your salary (or any other income) is related to the trade or business in the United States.

If you have more than one employer, you can claim a credit against your U.S. income tax liability for the maximum amount of Social Security tax you deduct in excess of the deduction. See Social Security and Medicare taxes, Chapter 8, for more information.

For any Medicare payroll or RRTA payments to you by your employer in 2024 that exceed $200,000, the employer is responsible for deducting an additional Medicare tax of 0.9% (0.009). If you do not owe Medicare taxes, you can file Form 8959, to claim a credit for any additional Medicare taxes that you deduct in order to meet your total tax liability shown on your tax return.

If you are a shareholder in a mutual fund, or other regulated investment company (RIC), or real estate investment trust (REIT), you may be able to claim a credit for your share of the tax paid by the company on its undistributed long-term capital gains. You will receive information about Form 2439 and you must attach the change to your tax return.

You may claim any tax withheld at source for investments and other FDAP income paid to you as tax paid. Fixed or determinable income includes interest, dividends, rent and royalties on income that you did not claim as closely related. Wages or salaries may be payments to you as fixed or determinable income, but are usually subject to the above withholding tax.

If you are a foreign partner of a joint venture, the joint venture may deduct tax on your share of the closely related taxable income (ECTI) from the joint venture. The joint venture will provide you with a statement on Form 8805 indicating that the tax has been deducted. The listed joint venture may deduct tax on the actual distribution of your closely related income. In this case, the joint venture will provide you with a statement on Form 1042-S.

If you are a direct or indirect partner of a U.S. or foreign joint venture that is engaged in (or is deemed to be engaged in) trade or transactions in the United States, and you directly or indirectly dispose of a taxable interest in the gain on the sale, you will pay to the IRS on your behalf for a transfer that occurs after 2017 that the beneficiary would normally deduct equal to 10% of the tax on the sale amount. The rules for deducting and paying that amount are similar to those for selling U.S. real estate interests. You will receive a deduction reflecting the amount of the deduction, at which point you can apply to your Form 1040-NR 25f for the transfer of that amount as a deduction for the tax on the gain on the sale you owe. You may provide certain information to the beneficiary to reduce or eliminate the deduction. For example, if the tax deduction is not recognized under the tax law and the tax deduction is not recognized under the tax law, you may provide a description of the deduction and/or's gain on the sale, but you may be notified in advance of the advance of the gain on the sale, if the beneficiary is not eligible to receive the tax deduction.
