You may claim any withholding tax on the disposition of U.S. real property interests (or income that is treated as income from the disposition of U.S. real property interests). See Chapter 4, Real Property Gains or Losses. The buyer will provide you with a statement of the amount of the withholding tax on Form 8288-A.

When you fill in your tax return, be especially careful to fill in the correct amount of tax deduction on the information sheet. The table below lists some of the more common information documents and shows where to look for the amount of tax deduction.

If you are a non-tax resident who is a true resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you generally pay tax as a resident. You must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, reporting all income received from sources outside the United States. However, you may deduct income discussed in the following paragraphs. However, for tax purposes other than reporting income, you are treated as a non-tax resident. For example, you are allowed to receive a standard deduction; you cannot file a joint return; you cannot apply for a dependent unless the person is a U.S. citizen or national. There are also restrictions on what deductions and exemptions are allowed.

If you are a full-time resident of Puerto Rico, you may deduct all income from Puerto Rico from your total income (except for service as an employee of the United States or any other agency) for the full year. If you report your income in a calendar year, you do not have to deduct wages for taxation in 2024, you must file your tax return and pay taxes by June 16, 2025, at the latest. You must also pay your first payment of estimated taxes for 2025 by June 16, 2025, at the latest.

If you are a true resident of American Samoa for the entire year of your birth, you may deduct from your total income all income derived from American Samoa (except for service as an employee of the United States Government or any agency thereof). Government employees of American Samoa are not considered employees of the United States Government or any agency thereof for the purpose of the deduction. For more information on these deductions, see Publications on Forms 4563 and 570.

You must calculate your income and file an income tax return during the annual accounting period known as the tax year. If you have not previously established a fiscal tax year, your tax year is the calendar year. The calendar year is the 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a normal fiscal tax year (that is, 12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than the 52nd or 53rd week of December) and you are considered a tax resident for any consecutive calendar year, you will be considered a tax resident for any period of the fiscal year within that calendar year.

You must provide a taxpayer identification number (TIN) on your tax return, returns, and other tax-related documents. For individuals, this number is the Social Security Number (SSN). If you do not have and are not eligible for a SSN, you must apply for a taxpayer identification number (ITIN). If you are engaged in a trade or business as a sole proprietor and have employees or qualifying retirement plans, you must provide an employer identification number (EIN). You must submit a TIN if you are: a foreign national who has income that is closely related to a trade or business in the United States at any time during the year; a foreign national who owns an office or business in the United States at any time during the year; a non-tax resident whose spouse is considered a tax resident as defined by the tax law, see Chapter 1 for discussion; or any other foreign national whose tax return is submitted with amended tax return information or tax return information but is not a tax return application.

Generally, you can get an SSN if you are lawfully admitted to the United States for permanent residence or are in one of the other immigrant categories that are granted employment in the United States. If you do not have an SSN, contact the Social Security Administration (SSA) to see if you are eligible for an SSN. For more information, visit SSA.gov or call 800-772-1213 (for deaf or hard of hearing people, call TTY 800-325-0778).

If you have an ITIN, enter it on your tax return whenever it is required. If you do not have an ITIN and are not eligible for an SSN, you must apply for an ITIN. For details on how to apply, see Form W-7 and its notes. If you are eligible for an ITIN and your application is complete, you will usually receive a letter from the IRS within 7 weeks allocating your tax identification number (TIN). If you do not receive an ITIN or other communication within 7 weeks of applying, if you are in the United States, please call the IRS toll-free at 800-829-1040 to check on the status of your application.

If you do not need to file a federal tax return in 2024, you must renew it. If you do not need to file a federal tax return, you do not need to renew your ITIN. If you need to renew your ITIN, see Form W-7 and its instructions: IRS.gov/FormW7 or IRS.gov/ITIN for more information. If your ITIN is not renewed, you may not renew it.

The amount of your tax depends on your tax status. Your tax status is crucial to determining whether you can make certain deductions and credits. The rules for determining your tax status are different for tax law definitions of resident and non-resident.
The tax law defines a resident as a person who uses the same tax identification as a U.S. citizen. For more information on tax identification, see the instructions for your form or Publication 501.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not remarry before the end of 2024, you may be eligible to file as a surviving spouse with a conditional survivor and use the joint return form. The above applies only if you filed a joint return with your spouse in the year of your spouse's death. For more information on the status of a surviving spouse with a conditional survivor, see the Conditional surviving spouse, which is included in the Form 1040 Explanation for 2024 and the Tax Return Status.

If you are unmarried or considered unmarried on the last day of the year and you pay more than half of the household expenses for yourself and qualifying dependents, you are a householder. You must be a resident for tax purposes for the entire tax year. If your spouse is a non-resident for tax purposes at any time during the year and does not choose to be a resident for tax purposes, you are considered unmarried for this purpose.
If you are a tax resident and you file Form 1040-NR, you can use the tax return status discussed below.

Non-tax law defines a married non-resident as a person who is not married to a U.S. citizen or resident, and who is not married to a U.S. citizen or resident. When determining income taxes that are closely related to U.S. trade or business, the tax column or tax calculation worksheet typically used for married persons to file a separate tax return must be used.

Married non-tax residents generally cannot file a tax return using the tax brackets or tax calculation worksheets used for single persons. However, if you lived separately from your spouse for the last 6 months of the year and you are a married Canadian, Mexican, Korean resident or a married U.S. citizen, you may file a tax return as a single person. See Form 1040-NR for details to see if you are eligible.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not remarry by the end of 2024, you are eligible to file a tax return as a qualifying surviving spouse and are eligible to use the joint tax return tax rate. For more information on qualifying surviving spouse tax status, see Qualifying surviving spouse tax status on Form 1040-NR, Explanation 2024.

If you are not a resident of a non-tax jurisdiction at any time during the taxable year, you cannot file a tax return as a household. However, if you are married, your spouse qualifies as a household if: your spouse is a resident or a U.S. citizen of a non-tax jurisdiction for the entire taxable year; you have not elected to be considered a resident of a tax jurisdiction; and your spouse meets the other requirements for this tax jurisdiction, see the section on the definition of a resident of a tax jurisdiction above.

If the nontax law defines a resident estate or trust as a resident estate or trust using Form 1040-NR, then the tax rate in the Form 1040-NR specification must be used to determine the taxation of income closely related to the trade or business in the United States.

Non-tax law defines a resident as a resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico who is a true resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire taxable year and who is temporarily employed in the United States. For information on special rules, see the section on a resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico at the end of this chapter.

You must report each taxable income according to the rules in the following chapters: Chapter 2, Chapter 3, and Chapter 4. For tax law definitions of residents, this includes income derived from sources outside the United States. For non-tax law definitions of residents, this includes income derived from a trade or business closely related to the United States (the progressive tax rate applies) and income derived from a non-close relationship with the United States (the uniform tax rate of 30% or a lower treaty rate applies).

D residents or non-residents may apply for a similar deduction on their U.S. tax returns. However, non-residents generally only apply for deductions related to income that is closely related to their U.S. trade or business activities.

You can apply for deductions to calculate your closely related taxable income (ECTI). Generally, you cannot apply for deductions to be associated with income that is not related to your U.S. business activities. Except for certain items discussed below, you can apply for deductions only if the deductions are closely related to your income.

If you have a daily and necessary expense in the course of conducting a trade or business in the United States that is closely related to the income of such business, you may deduct all such expense. For information on other business expenses, see the guide to business expense resources.

If you have paid conditional student loan interest in 2024, you may deduct up to $2,500 of the interest already paid. Generally, you may apply for a deduction if you meet all the requirements. The deduction is made on line 21 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) in the Annual Report.

If you have income that is closely related to your U.S. trade or business, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualifying business income from your qualifying trade or business, plus 20% of qualifying REIT dividends and qualifying publicly traded partnership (PTP) income. For details, see the contents of Form 1040-NR, Explanatory Notes, line 13a. For more information on the deduction of qualifying business income, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and its appendices, and the relevant notes to the forms and appendices.

You may deduct losses arising from transactions in which you participated for profit and for which you did not receive insurance, provided that such losses are related to income that is closely related to your trade or business in the United States.

If you are a qualified educator in 2024, you may deduct up to $300 of your 2024 tuition and fees for certain professional development courses, as well as for books, supplies (excluding non-sports supplies for health or physical education classes), computer equipment (including related software and services), and other supplemental equipment and materials you use in the classroom, as an income adjustment. For more information, see your tax return. Eligible expenses include amounts paid or incurred in 2024 for personal protective equipment, vaccines, and other consumables to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.

If you contribute to a Traditional IRA in 2024, you may be able to make IRA deductions. However, to do so, you must have taxable income closely related to your trade or business in the United States. Form 5498 should be sent to you by June 2, 2025, and shows all of your contributions to your Traditional IRA in 2024. If you are employed or self-employed, and you are enrolled in a pension plan, a defined benefit plan, a pension plan, a SEP, or a SIMPLE, your IRA deductions may be reduced or canceled.

Do not include the value of government-provided moving and storage services in your income, as this is a move made under military orders for permanent change of residence. Similarly, do not include amounts received as a moving allowance, temporary accommodation expenses, temporary accommodation allowance, or relocation allowance. For details, see the contents of Issue No. 3 (in English).

If you are self-employed, you can deduct contributions from the SEP, SIMPLE, or qualified retirement plans that provide retirement benefits for yourself and your common law employees (if any). To make deductible contributions for yourself, you must have self-employed net income and be closely related to your U.S. trade or business.

You must include in your income all interest you receive or closely related interest credited to your account during the year. You must not deduct any penalty you must pay for withdrawing deposits from your periodic savings account in advance. However, if the interest income is closely related to your trade or business in the United States for the year, you may deduct the amount of the penalty for withdrawals from a bank institution on the basis of the withdrawal requirement in line 18 of Schedule 1 on Form 1040, which is attached to Form 1040-NR.

If you do not provide the SSN, ITIN, or adoption tax identification number (ATIN) of the dependent child on your tax return, or if the number you provide is incorrect, some tax benefits will be refused. See the contents of the identification number above.

If you are a tax resident, and the qualifying dependent includes your qualifying child or qualifying relative. To be a qualifying child, you must pass five tests. To be a qualifying relative, you must pass five tests. For more information, please refer to Form 1040.

If you are a resident of Mexico or Canada or a U.S. citizen, you may apply for each of your dependents who pass certain tests. The same rules as U.S. citizens must be used to determine who is a dependent. See Publication No. 501 (in English) for these rules.

Non-resident Korean tax law defines a resident (except for Korean government employees) as a dependent whose children may apply for the status of dependent. In addition to using the same rules as US citizens, the child must also have been living in the US with the non-resident for a period of time during the tax year, in accordance with the income tax treaty with South Korea, which determines who is a dependent.

Students and apprentices of businesses who are eligible under Section 21 (2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Agreement may apply for their family members to be considered as dependents if they meet the rules applicable to U.S. citizens.

You are both a resident and a nonresident for tax purposes in the same tax year. Dual citizenship does not refer to your citizenship; it refers only to your tax residency in the United States. When determining your U.S. income tax liability for a tax year in which you are a resident, different rules apply for any period of the year in which you are a nonresident. The most common dual citizenship years are the years of entry and exit.

If you do not file income tax returns on a calendar year basis, you must file your tax return by the 15th day of the 4th month following the end of your tax year. You must file an income tax return for the taxable year in which you are taxable. If you have not previously established a fiscal year, your taxable year is the calendar year. If the calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a normal fiscal year (i.e., 12 consecutive months ending on the last day of the calendar month other than December or the 52-53 week) and you are considered a taxable resident on any date in the calendar year, you will be considered a taxable resident for any period in the fiscal year within that calendar year.

If you are a non-tax resident, you may be entitled to receive tax relief from certain taxable income in the United States, which may be taxable to you, and you may be entitled to receive tax relief from certain taxable income in the United States, which may be taxable to you, and you may be entitled to receive tax relief from certain taxable income, which may be taxable to you, and which may be taxable to you, except in certain circumstances, such as taxation agreements between you, your non-resident, and the United States, which may be applicable to you, and tax relief may be granted to you, and you may be entitled to receive tax relief from certain taxable income, which may be taxable to you, and which may be applicable to you, except in certain circumstances, such as taxation agreements between you, your non-resident, and the United States, which may be applicable to you, and which may be applicable to you, and which may be applicable to you, and which may be applicable to you, and which may be applicable to you, and to you, and to you, and to you, and to your family, and to you, and to your children, and grandchildren, and grandchildren, and grandchildren, and grandchildren, and grandchildren, and grandchildren, and grandchildren, and grandchildren, and grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchildren, grandchild
If you file an annual tax return in a dual-status taxation system, the following limitations apply:
You cannot use the standard deductions allowed on a Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. However, you may list any deductions that are exempt on a case-by-case basis.
You cannot file a joint return. However, see the definition of residency in the Tax Code, which is contained in Chapter 1 Dual Status Aliens.

If you are a dual-status taxpayer, you may apply for a dependent on your tax return. Generally, a dependent is a qualifying child or qualifying relative. If you have a qualifying dependent, you are entitled to apply for additional deductions and credits.

All income during the period of your tax law definition as a resident and all income during the period of your tax law definition as a non-resident that is closely related to a trade or business in the United States, plus any deductible deductions, and taxed at the applicable tax rate for U.S. citizens and residents. All income during the period of your tax law definition as a non-resident that is not closely related to a trade or business in the United States is taxed at the 30% flat rate or the lower agreement tax rate. You may not deduct any deductions from this income.

For the part of the year that you are a non-tax law resident, 85% of any U.S. Social Security benefits you receive (and the equivalent portion of Class 1 railroad retirement benefits) are taxed at the flat rate of 30% (unless tax-exempt) or the lower agreed tax rate. If your adjusted gross income plus half of these benefits exceeds certain basic amounts, then for the part of the year that you are a tax law resident, you are subject to progressive taxation at the same rate as your Social Security and Class 1 railroad retirement benefits. As a dual-citizen alien, you generally can apply for a tax credit using the same rules that apply to the tax law definition of resident. There may be some applicable restrictions. These restrictions, as well as a brief explanation of the credit that individuals often apply for, are discussed here. You cannot apply for an education credit, a low-income family benefit, or an elderly or disabled benefit unless you are married and choose to be treated as a full-time resident in 2024 by filing jointly with a spouse of a U.S. citizen or resident, as discussed in Chapter 1.

If you have already paid income tax in another country on income from another country, or if you are liable to pay income tax, you can apply for a foreign tax credit. If you apply for a foreign tax credit, you must usually submit Form 1116 and your income tax return.

You are eligible for the deduction if you have a dependent parent who is a taxpayer and who is taking care of your qualifying child under the age of 13, or your disabled dependent parent or disabled spouse so that you can work or find work. Only married dual-status aliens who choose to file the joint return discussed in Chapter 1 or who are married to a person who is not a taxpayer and who qualifies for certain separated individual status are eligible for the deduction.

The dependent child allowance is for children of dependent parents who: are not eligible for the child tax credit; are a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or tax resident, and have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the 2024 tax return due date;

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for the concession fee for an eligible child. The amount is allowed for the adoption of a child with special needs, regardless of whether you qualify for the concession fee. To apply for the adoption credit, file Form 8839 and your U.S. income tax return. You may qualify for the credit only if you are a married dual-status alien who has selected a spouse as a non-tax resident for the purposes of the taxation of the spouse's taxable income, as defined in Chapter 1, or if you qualify as a certain separated spouse (see Form 8839 for married spouses who have not filed a joint return).

You may file a tax return for certain U.S. income tax obligations that you have paid, are deemed to have paid, or have withheld from your income. These include: withholding taxes on wages earned in the United States; withholding taxes on income from sources other than wages in the United States; estimated taxes paid on Form 1040-ES or Form 1040-ES (NR); and taxes paid on Form 1040-C when you leave the United States.
The U.S. income tax return that you must file as a dual-citizen alien depends on whether you are a resident or non-resident at the end of the tax year.

If you are a taxpayer with dual status who became a resident of the United States during the tax year and became a resident of the United States on the last day of the tax year, you must file Form 1040 and Form 1040-SR. Fill in the Dual-Status Return at the top of the tax return.

If you are a taxpayer with dual status who renounces tax law definition of resident status during the year and is not a tax law definition of resident on the last day of the tax year, you must file Form 1040-NR. Enter the Dual-Status Return at the top of the tax return. Attach your statement to your tax return, showing your income during the year you renounce tax law definition of resident status. You may use Form 1040-NR or Form 1040-SR as a statement, but must enter the Dual-Status Statement at the top of the tax return. If you renounce citizenship or terminate your right to reside in 2024, you may need to file Form 8854 with your tax return.
The tax return you must file, and when and where, depends on whether you are a tax resident or a non-tax resident at the end of the tax year.

If you are a resident, you must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, which is located at the address listed on the Form 1040 instruction. The deadline for filing your tax return and paying any tax due is April 15 of the year following the year in which you file your return.

If you file Form 4868 before the due date for your tax return, you are allowed an automatic extension of 6 months. If you file Form 4868 before the due date for your tax return, you are allowed an automatic extension of 6 months. If you file Form 4868 before the due date for your tax return, you are allowed an automatic extension of 6 months. If you file Form 4868 before the due date for your tax return, you are allowed an automatic extension of 6 months. If you file Form 4868 before the due date for your tax return, you are entitled to a special extension of 4 months. If you file Form 4868 before the due date for your tax return, you are entitled to a special extension of 6 months.

You may also be required to file a tax return if you wish to: apply for an excess deduction or refund of excess tax paid; or apply for any deduction or credit for benefits. For example, if you are not engaged in a U.S. business, but you have real estate income from income that you choose to consider closely related (see the description in Chapter 4), you must file a true and accurate tax return in a timely manner to make any deductible deductions on that income.
If you are married, you and your spouse must file a separate tax return. If you are married, you must file a separate tax return.

If you are an employee whose salary is subject to U.S. withholding tax, you must normally file your tax return by the 15th day of the 4th month following the end of your tax year. For the calendar year 2024, file your tax return by April 15, 2025. If you are not an employee whose salary is subject to U.S. withholding tax, you must file your tax return by the 15th day of the 6th month following the end of your tax year. For the calendar year 2024, file your tax return by June 16, 2025.

If you are unable to file your tax return by the due date, you may file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic filing options explained in the Form 4868 Statement. For the calendar year 2024, doing so will extend the due date to October 15, 2025. If your normal due date is June 16, 2025, this will extend the due date to December 15, 2025. You may have to file your tax return by the due date.

If your activities in the United States are restricted and you believe that you did not generate any gross income during the year that was closely related to your trade or business in the United States, you may file a tax return that gives you protection before the above deadline (Form 1040-NR). If you file a tax return that gives you protection, you may protect your right to receive deductions and tax benefits if: If it is determined that all or part of your income is closely related at a later date. You are not required to report any unrelated income or any deductions on the tax return that gives you protection, but you must give reasons for filing the tax return. If you believe that some of your activities generate closely related income, please file a tax return before the normal deadline, reporting that income and the related deductions. To protect your right to deduct or credit income generated by other activities, please include a statement on the tax return explaining that if you determine that you would like to generate other closely related income, you may be entitled to the same deductions and tax benefits as you would have received under the U.S. Taxpayer Protection Act (Form 1040-NR). If you do not have the same rights to deduct income, you may be subject to the same procedures as for filing U.S. Taxpayer protection under the O-NR.

If you determine, based on facts and circumstances, that your failure to file a U.S. income tax return (including a protected return) was justified and in good faith, and you cooperate with the IRS in determining your liability for U.S. income tax for the tax year for which you failed to file the return, the IRS may waive the filing deadline.

If an item on your tax return is a legitimate tax avoidance, it is not deductible for full disclosure. However, it may be deductible for substantial authority, but only if you reasonably believe that your tax treatment is likely to be fair.

Whether the tax treatment of a project is or has been substantial depends on the facts and circumstances. Consideration should be given to court opinions, Treasury regulations, tax rulings, tax procedures, and notices and announcements issued by the Internal Revenue Service and published on the Internal Revenue Service's bulletin board, which relate to the same or similar circumstances as you.

If you are required to disclose fully the relevant facts about your tax treatment of a project, use Form 8275, Disclosure Statement. You must also have a good reason for handling the project in the way you did before. If there is a significant underreporting of income taxes, only projects that meet the requirements of IRS Procedural Guidelines 2024-44, IRS.gov/irb/2024-52_IRB#REV-PROC-2024-44 (or its subsequent versions) are considered to be fully disclosed on your tax return. If there is a change in the tax laws for tax years beginning after December 31, 2024, and the effect of that change is not considered, then Tax Procedure No.

If you show sufficient reasons for the way you handled a project, you do not have to pay the fine. You must also show that you acted in good faith. This provision does not apply to transactions that lack economic substance.

If you file a negligent tax return or other negligent tax report, you must pay a $5,000 fine. Negligent tax returns are those that do not contain sufficient information to calculate the correct tax; they contain information that clearly indicates that your tax report is seriously incorrect. For more information about negligent tax returns and negligent filings and the list of those determined to be negligent, see IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (or later). If you file a tax return or other tax report based on negligence, or based on intentional delay or interference with the implementation of federal tax law, you must pay a fine. This includes the modification or deletion of the language for your signature to be printed. This is in addition to any other penalties provided by law.

If you fail to include your Social Security Number (SSN) or Personal Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) on your tax return, return, or other document as required, or someone else's SSN or ITIN, you may be subject to a $50 fine for each failure to do so. You may also be subject to a $50 fine if you fail to provide your SSN or ITIN on a tax return, return, or other document that requires your SSN or ITIN. For example, if you have a bank account that you can use to earn interest, you must provide your SSN or ITIN to the bank. The number must be listed on Form 1099-INT or other statements the bank sends you. If you fail to provide your SSN or ITIN to the bank, you will be subject to a $50 fine.

If you have paid at least 90% of your actual tax liability on or before your tax return due date and filed a balance of tax payments, the above penalty will not apply during the automatic 6-month rollover period of your tax return. If you have paid at least 1⁄2% (0.005) of the unpaid tax you paid for each month you have not paid taxes. If you have not paid at least 1⁄2% (0.005) of the unpaid tax you paid for each month you have paid taxes. If you have not paid interest and have not been notified of the increase in interest rate by the first day of the month you are required to pay the tax return, you will not be entitled to a penalty of at least 1⁄2% (0.005) and if you have not paid interest and have not paid interest within the first 6 months from the date of the first filing of your tax return due date. If you have not paid the tax you have paid after the due date, you will be entitled to a penalty of at least 1⁄2% (0.005) and if you have not paid interest and have not paid interest until the due date of the first month you have paid your tax return due. If you have not paid the tax return due by the first day of the due date you have not paid the interest and have not paid the interest until the due date of the first month you paid your return return is due. If you have not paid your tax return due, you will not be notified of the deduction of the interest and the interest rate within the first 6 months from the due date of your filing of your filing of your return due date.

If you fully disclose your position on the tax return, at least on reasonable grounds, you may be exempt from the penalty for failure to comply with the regulations and regulations. See the disclosure statement below. This exception does not apply to projects that can be attributed to legal means of tax avoidance.

This chapter discusses how to pay your income tax when you earn or receive income during the year. Generally, federal income tax is a cash tax. There are two ways to pay cash tax. If you are an employee, your employer may deduct income tax from your salary. It may also be deducted from some other income, including pensions, bonuses, commissions, and gambling income. In each case, the amount of the deduction will be transferred to the U.S. Treasury on your behalf.

You must inform your employer whether you are a tax law definition resident or a tax law definition nonresident so that your employer can deduct the correct amount of tax from your wages. If you are a tax law definition resident under the rules discussed in Chapter 1, you must submit a Form W-9 or similar statement to your employer. If you are a tax law definition nonresident under these rules, you must provide your employer with Form 8233 or Form W-8BEN, proving that you are a foreigner; or W-4, proving that your remuneration is subject to the same tax rate as a tax law definition resident or a U.S. citizen, and that you pay the accrual deduction. If you are a tax law definition resident and you derive income from outside the United States from sources other than employment income (such as shares and preferential use), please deduct the advance payment to the tax agent (usually the payment to the tax agent is an income deduction) on Form W-9 so that the agent will not be subject to a deduction at a rate similar to the 30% deduction of the income taxable agent's income under the tax law or to a deduction of the income taxable agent's income (if the tax agent is a resident or a nonresident) if you are a resident of the United States, but you are not subject to a deduction under the taxation agreement to pay the deduction, but if you are subject to the deduction of the deduction of the income deduction as defined in the tax law).

The following discussion generally applies only to non-tax law definitions of resident. Resident tax deductions are defined to the tax law in the same way as tax deductions to U.S. citizens. Wages and other remuneration paid to a resident for services performed by a resident as an employee are generally taxed at the same rate as a resident and tax law definition of resident, with progressive income tax deductions. Therefore, unless your remuneration is explicitly excluded from the Fixed Wage (wage) Allowance by law, or exempt from taxation under an agreement, you are required to deduct progressive tax on that remuneration.

If you are an employee and you receive wages that are subject to advance taxation, you must file Form W-4. You must also file Form W-4 for a scholarship or research grant, to the extent that such scholarship or research grant represents services you have provided in the past, present or future, and for such funds you have not filed a tax-deferred tax return on Form 8233 (the income from which you are entitled to tax treaties is discussed below). These services are provided as part of the employee benefits and are subject to the payment of a scholarship or research grant (or deduction of tuition fees). Non-tax residents are defined as employees who perform services for which they are paid in the United States on a self-employed basis.
If you are eligible for a tax deduction under Section 21 (2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Agreement, you may claim an additional deduction of the standard deduction.
If you are a domestic worker, your employer does not have to withhold income tax. However, you have to submit a W-4 form to your employer and agree to voluntary withholding of income tax.

If you are an agricultural worker on an H-2A visa, your employer is not required to withhold income tax. However, your employer may withhold income tax only if you and your employer agree to withhold it. In this case, you must provide your employer with a properly completed Form W-4.

Wages exempt from U.S. income tax under income tax laws are generally exempt from withholding taxes. For information on how to apply for this withholding tax exemption, see the section entitled "Eligible Income Benefits". Wages paid to foreign nationals who are residents of American Samoa, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico, or the U.S. Virgin Islands. These exemptions are explained in the following paragraphs.
The declaration can take any form, but must be dated and signed by the employee and must include a written clarification of penalties such as perjury.

If you are a resident employee of an American Samoa or Puerto Rico resident, the non-tax law defines the non-tax law as a resident employee, wages for services performed in American Samoa or Puerto Rico are generally not subject to withholding tax unless you are an employee of the United States or of any agency of the United States in American Samoa or Puerto Rico.

Non-taxable persons who are actual residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands are defined as residents who are exempt from paying U.S. withholding tax on income earned temporarily while working in the United States. This is because such persons pay income tax to the U.S. Virgin Islands. In order for withholding tax to be levied on income earned in the United States, a resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands should send a letter to his or her employer (one or two copies) stating that he or she is a resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands and wishes to pay tax on all income earned in the U.S. Virgin Islands.

If you receive a pension from the United States, the payment is usually tax deductible at the 30% (or lower) tax rate agreed upon. However, for the portion of the pension that is earned from service in the United States after 1986, you may have the portion of the pension deducted by someone else at a progressive tax rate.

Tips received during a year of service in the United States are subject to U.S. income tax. They are included in taxable income. In addition, tips received for a month when you work for an employer totaling more than $20 are subject to progressive tax withholding.

If you and the person for whom you perform services have no employee-employer relationship, your compensation is subject to withholding tax at the 30% rate (or lower by agreement). However, if you engaged in trade or business in the United States during the taxable year, the compensation for personal services you provided as an independent contractor (independent personal services) may be exempt from withholding tax in whole or in part if you have an agreement with the IRS regarding the amount of the withholding tax necessary.

If you are a non-tax resident alien performing or participating in a sporting event in the United States, you may enter into a CWA with the IRS, reducing the withholding tax if certain requirements are met. In no event will the withholding tax agreement reduce the withholding tax to less than the anticipated amount of income tax liability. For non-tax resident aliens or athletes earning at least $10,000 in gross U.S. income for any calendar year to date, you may apply using Form 13930 to apply for a CWA. If you are a non-tax resident alien performing or participating in a sporting event in the United States, you may file Form 13930 using the same form.

If the IRS is satisfied with this information, it will determine the amount of your provisional income tax for the taxable year on your total income closely related to your trade or business in the United States. Such expenditures may be considered if the IRS Administrator or the IRS Administrator's representative demonstrates satisfaction with normal and necessary business expenses. The IRS Administrator or the IRS Administrator's representative will send you a letter to the withholding agent stating the amount of the final tax payment for the exemption and the amount that may be paid to you as a result of the exemption.

If you are a distributor of a MLM company that has been tax-deductible, file a U.S. income tax return (Form 1040-NR or 1120-F); or, if you have filed a tax return, file a claim for a refund of the tax deduction amount (Form 1040-X or the revised version of Form 1120-F). You must also include supporting information on your U.S. income tax return or refund application, including but not limited to the following items: a copy of Form 1042-S or Form 1099 showing the amount of tax withheld. A statement explaining why you have not paid your portion of the income tax due on Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099. A statement listing your days in the tax year in which you entered and departed the U.S. for a full period of time. If you are eligible for compensation, the statement must list the number of days in the tax year in which you departed the U.S. for a full period of time. The following documents must be used to support the tax return or refund application, including but not limited to the following items: (a) the number of days in the tax year in which you departed, the tax return, or the number of the tax deduction amount of the tax due due for a full period of time, or the tax year in which you entered the tax return, or the tax return, or any other supporting documentation for the tax period in which you were employed, or performed by the following services provided by the U. If you are a green card holder, your Social Security benefits are tax deductible incorrectly because you have a foreign address. The IRS should refund the tax deduction. If you are a green card holder, your Social Security benefits are tax deductible incorrectly because you have a foreign address, the IRS should refund the tax deduction. If you are a resident of the United States and have not filed a tax return with the IRS for the tax year, you should file the following tax return: I am a resident of the United States and have not filed my Social Security benefits as a tax deduction because my income has not been taxed as a taxable income in the United States nor as a taxable income in the United States.

Other income subject to a 30% deduction (or lower agreement tax rate) generally includes fixed or determinable income, such as interest (excluding portfolio interest), dividends, pensions and annuities, and certain proceeds from sales and exchanges, see Chapter 4. It also includes 85% of the amount of social security benefits paid to residents as defined by the non-tax law.
The special rules on deductions for income, scholarships and grants of joint ventures are explained below.

If you are a foreign partner of a U.S. or foreign joint venture, the joint venture may deduct a deduction on your share of the effective taxable income (ECTI) derived from the joint venture. Your joint venture may consider a deduction at certain partner levels to deduct the deduction on your ECTI share. Generally, for this purpose, you must file Form 8804-C. For more information, see the Explanation to Form 8804-C. The deduction tax rate on your closely related income is usually the highest tax rate (37%) set forth in Section 1. However, if you provide the joint venture with the proper documentation, the joint venture will deduct the tax at the highest tax rate that may be appropriately allocated to you for the special type of income.

If you are a partner, direct or indirect, of a U.S. or foreign joint venture that is engaged in (or is deemed to be engaged in) trade or transactions within the United States, and you directly or indirectly dispose of a taxable interest in the gain on the sale that occurs after 2017, you will pay the IRS on your behalf. The rules for withholding and paying that amount are similar to those for selling U.S. real estate interests. You will receive an amount reflecting the withholding, at which time you may apply for a credit transfer of the amount as a taxable interest in the gain on the sale you owe on your Form 1040-NR 25f. You may provide certain information to the beneficiary to reduce or eliminate the withholding tax. For example, if the taxable interest is not recognized by the tax law in the country where the taxable interest is located, the beneficiary will generally be required to withhold 10% of the taxable interest in the gain on the sale, and if you provide a description of the withholding tax in the gain on the sale that is not recognized, you may be required to pay the IRS on your behalf. However, the rule for withholding and payment of that amount is similar to the rule for the amount reflecting the withholding amount you receive on Form 8288-A, at which you may apply to the amount of the taxable interest due on the gain on the transfer. You may transfer the amount to the beneficiary, in accordance with the provisions of the Final Rule of Form 1040-NR-NR 25f, transfer, transfer the amount of the 25f, transfer of the 25f, the 25f, the 25f, the 25f, the 46-NR-NR-NR-NR-NR-NR-NR-NR-NR-NR-T, or the 25F, or the 46-NR-NR-NR-NR-T, or the 46-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-T-

If you are a non-U.S. citizen foreign student or recipient of a grant or scholarship of U.S. origin who is not fully tax-exempt on an F, J, M, Q, or Q visa, the tax on the grant or scholarship portion of the payment for non-service grants is deductible by the tax agent (usually the grant payer) at a 14% (or lower) agreement tax rate. However, if you are not a degree candidate and the grant does not meet certain requirements, the tax on the grant portion of the payment for the grant or scholarship portion of the payment for service grants is deductible at a 30% (or lower) agreement tax rate.
You can deduct the tax-free portion of your grant or scholarship according to the laws of the United States or the tax treaty.
If you are a qualifying student under Section 21 (2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Act, you can claim the standard deduction of $14,600 in 2024.

If you file Form W-4 to deduct or eliminate the withholding tax on your scholarship or grant, you must file a U.S. income tax return each year that allows you to claim any withholding tax on the form. If you are in the United States for more than one tax year, you must attach a statement to your annual Form W-4 that you have filed the previous year's U.S. income tax return. If you are in the United States for a shorter period of time and do not need to file a tax return, you must attach a statement to your Form W-4 that you file your U.S. income tax return when necessary. If the withholding tax agent accepts your Form W-4, the withholding tax will be applied to your scholarship or grant grant grant, based on the applicable withholding tax deduction rate.

If you are a resident of the United States and you have tax treaty rights to exempt you from certain income taxes or to reduce certain income tax rates, you should notify the payer of your income (the tax withholding agent) of your status as a foreigner for tax purposes. You may file with the tax withholding agent either a Form W-8BEN or Form 8233. For income from non-personal services, you may file Form W-8BEN. For income from personal services, discussed below, you may file Form 8233. If you have tax treaty rights to exemption, you may still qualify for the tax credit by filing Form 1040-NR, even if you have not filed Form 8233 with your tax withholding agent. Please see Form 1040-NR, line 1a for details.

If you perform personal services as an employee or as an independent contractor, you may apply for a tax credit for the personal service tax under the tax agreement by filing Form 8233 with each tax creditor who pays you. Even if you file Form 8233, the tax creditor must withhold tax from your income. This is because the factors on which the tax credit is based may not be determined before the end of the tax year. In this case, you must file Form 1040-NR to collect the tax credit; and you must submit to the IRS a certificate that you are entitled to the tax credit.

Students, faculty, and researchers must attach the appropriate statement shown at the end of this publication in Annex A (for student use) or Annex B (for faculty and researchers use) to Form 8233 and submit it to the tax withholding agent. For agreements not listed in the Annex, the attached statement is in a format similar to that of other agreements. If you receive scholarships or research grants and personal service income from the same tax withholding agent, please use Form 8233 to apply for a tax withholding agreement based on both types of income.

For payments to non-tax law defined resident or foreign corporations for ticket revenue for music festivals, boxing promotions, and other entertainment or sports events, or television or other income, a withholding is required at the 30% full rate of tax unless the withholding agent receives special notice from the IRS in a letter. For more information on how to withhold tax, see the CWA Form 13930 for more details, which is available in English. Even if the income is exempt from tax under the tax treaty, a withholding is required.

The buyer must file Form 8288, complete and pay the tax withholding tax within 20 days of the transfer. This form is submitted to the IRS along with copies A and B of Form 8288-A. If this statement is complete and contains your TIN, copy B of the statement is delivered to the IRS, stamped and returned to the buyer. You must submit copy B and your tax return to receive the tax credit. If your TIN is not included in Form 8288-A, you will not be provided with a copy of the form stamped.

If you are an employee working in the United States, you must pay Social Security and Medicare taxes in most cases. Paying these taxes ensures that you receive benefits under the U.S. Social Security system. Social Security benefits cover retirement, inheritance, and disability benefits, as well as Medicare benefits, for individuals who meet certain eligibility requirements. In most cases, you can apply for Social Security benefits for $168,600 of taxable income earned before you provide services in the United States in 2024. You are free to use your Social Security number. You are not entitled to unemployment insurance. You are not covered by any income tax.

There are no special provisions for non-tax-dependent defined benefit plans for non-tax-dependent residents. You may also be able to claim a deduction and/or estimated tax deduction on Form W-4 if you are required to pay Medicare taxes on wages, RRTA payments, and self-employed income that exceeds the applicable threshold. You may be able to claim a deduction of 0.9% (0.009) on Medicare taxes or RRTA payments paid to you by your employer in a calendar year. You may also be able to claim a deduction for Medicare taxes on your income from health insurance coverage. You may be able to claim a deduction for Medicare taxes if you intend to file a joint return and you and your spouse are expected to have a combined personal income of less than $200,000 but your total salary and self-employed income exceeds $250,000.

If you are a non-tax resident who is temporarily admitted to the United States as a student, you are generally not allowed to work for pay or wages or engage in business activities while in the United States. In some cases, students are allowed to enter the United States as F-1, M-1, or J-1 residents, and are granted a work permit. Unless a student is considered a tax resident, social security and Medicare taxes are not deducted from their work pay. Any student who enrolls in a school and attends classes regularly and receives wages for services rendered by the school is exempt from paying Social Security and Medicare taxes.

Exchange students are temporarily admitted to the United States under Section 101 (a) (j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Unless the exchange student is a resident as defined by the tax code, the services of the exchange student who has obtained a work permit and who holds or has obtained a sponsorship authorization are not subject to deduction of social security and health insurance taxes from the salary. If the services performed by the exchange student are not considered to be in accordance with the purpose of their admission to the United States, then social security and health insurance taxes are deducted from the salary unless the exchange student is exempt from the tax code.

If you have a deduction of Medicare taxes from your salary in error, you may file Form 8959 and Form 1040-SR or Form 1040-NR for a deduction of Medicare taxes for any Medicare taxes that you have deducted in order to satisfy your total tax liability shown on your tax return. If you have already filed Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR or Form 1040-NR for a deduction of Medicare taxes in error for a year, you may file Form 1040-SR or Form 1040-NR for the first year of your salary or compensation, and you may not be able to recover Medicare taxes deducted in error.

Agricultural workers who are temporarily admitted to the United States on an H-2A visa are exempt from Social Security and Medicare taxes for compensation for services rendered in connection with their H-2A visa. You can find more information about tax deductions at IRS.gov/ForeignAgriculturalWorkers.

Self-employment tax is a social security and health insurance tax levied on self-employed persons. Non-tax residents are not required to pay self-employment tax unless a valid international social security agreement determines that they are covered by the U.S. social security system. Residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, or American Samoa are treated as residents for this purpose and are required to pay self-employment tax. You can find more information about the International Security Agreement below.

The tax is to be reported and calculated using the following form: SE (form 1040); then the input tax is added to the form 1040 (form 1040-SR or form 1040-NR) in the fourth line of the form 2 (form 1040).

If you have both a salary and self-employed income, the threshold for the self-employed income tax deduction is reduced to the amount of the salary for which the self-employed income is subject to the self-employed income tax deduction (but not less than zero). Self-employed losses are not to be considered for this tax purpose. If you file Form 1040-NR, if you are married (if you tick the married tax return box at the top of Form 1040-NR page 1), if your total salary and self-employed income exceeds $125,000, or if your self-employed income exceeds $200,000, if you are single or living as a cohabiting partner (if you tick the cohabiting partner box at the top of Form 1040-NR page 1), you must pay the self-employed income tax deduction.
If you have to pay self-employment tax, you can deduct part of the tax paid from your income after adjustment for the total income tax.

The United States has concluded social security agreements with foreign countries, often called "totalization agreements", that coordinate social security coverage and taxation for those who complete part or all of their careers in one of the countries. Under these agreements, double insurance and double contributions for the same job are eliminated. These agreements typically ensure that social security taxes (including self-employment taxes) are paid to only one country. For current international security agreements, see SSA.gov/international/status.html (in English).

In general, these agreements require you to pay social security taxes only in the country where you work. However, if you are temporarily sent to the United States to work for the same employer, and your salary is usually subject to social security taxes in both countries, most agreements stipulate that you are covered only by the social security system of the country of origin. To determine if your salary is subject to foreign social security taxes only, and is exempt from U.S. social security taxes (including Medicare taxes) under the agreement, you or your employer should seek an insurance certificate from the appropriate foreign agency. This is usually the same agency that you or your employer paid foreign social security taxes to. Foreign agencies will be able to tell you what information they need to issue the certificate. Your employer should keep a copy of the certificate, as it may be required only to explain why you are exempt from paying U.S. social security taxes on the day or after the agreement comes into effect.

If you are a self-employed person and you are covered by the social security system of your country of residence, you are covered by the social security system of your country of residence. However, under some agreements, you may be exempt from paying U.S. self-employment tax if you temporarily transfer your business activities to or from the United States. If you believe that your self-employed income is subject to U.S. self-employment tax only and exempt from foreign social security tax, you should obtain an insurance certificate from the Social Security Administration.

If you are not a resident of a state where your adjusted gross income for 2024 is less than $150,000 (or $75,000 if you are a married person and filed a separate tax return in 2025) and you are not a farmer or fisherman, use 110% (1.10) instead of 100% (1.00) in the above (2) If you do not file your 2024 tax return, then (2) does not apply. Non-tax law residents are defined as those who use Form 1040-ES (NR) to calculate and pay estimated tax.

If you filed your 2024 tax return on Form 1040-NR and expect your 2025 income and total deductions to be nearly the same, you should use your 2024 tax return as a guide to fill out the estimated tax worksheet in the Form 1040-ES (NR) Statement. If you did not file your 2024 tax return, or if your income, deductions, or credits differed in 2025, you must estimate those amounts.

Even if you do not have to pay the estimated tax in April or June, your circumstances may change and you must pay the estimated tax after that. If you receive additional income or any of your deductions are reduced or eliminated, this may occur. If so, see the Explanatory Notes to Form 1040-ES (NR) and Publication No. 505 for information on calculating your estimated tax.

If you find that your estimated income after you have paid your estimated tax has increased or decreased substantially because of changes in your income or tax-exempt status, you should adjust the estimated income. For this, see the Explanatory Notes to Form 1040-ES (NR) and Publication No. 505.
You will be fined for underpayment of your estimated tax, except in certain circumstances. These are explained on Form 2210.

The Federal Disaster Relief Act of 2023 extends special provisions and tax return procedures for reporting personal injury losses due to certain major federal disasters declared between February 26, 2021 and February 10, 2025. Eligible disaster losses may be reported on Form 4684 - Personal Injury and Theft. For more information, see the section below on Qualified Disaster Losses.

The 2019 Taxpayer Determination and Disaster Tax Relief Act and the 2020 Taxpayer Determination and Disaster Tax Relief Act extend the special rules and reporting procedures for personal accidental loss for certain federal disasters announced in 2018, 2019 and 2020 by 10% for each disaster. In these tax years, qualified disaster losses can be reported on Form 4684. Please see the qualified disaster loss statement below for more information. If applicable, you may have to file Form 1040-X, as amended, to file these benefits on your 2018/19 and/or 2020 tax returns. Form 1040-X can be found on IRS.gov/Form 1040-Q. The deduction for personal injury can be found on Form 100684 for each disaster.

This publication explains the tax treatment of accidental accidents, thefts, and deposit loss. Accidental accidents are when a disaster such as a storm, fire, car accident, or similar event causes damage to your property. Theft occurs when someone steals your property. Deposit loss occurs when your financial situation becomes insolvent or bankrupt.

The 584-B Manual for the Work of Losses from Accidents, Disasters, and Thefts in Businesses ("Personal Use Property") can help you prepare a list of your stolen or damaged personal use property and calculate your losses. It includes several detailed tables to help you calculate the loss of your home and its contents, as well as the loss of motor vehicles. The 584-B Manual for the Work of Losses from Accidents, Disasters, and Thefts in Businesses ("Business Accidents, Disasters, and Thefts in Businesses") can help you prepare a list of your stolen or damaged business property or the loss of your property and calculate your losses.

All three categories of disaster are those declared by the federal government, but the requirements for each type of disaster are different. Disasters declared by the federal government are those decided by the President of the United States, authorizing federal assistance under the Stafford Act. Disasters declared by the federal government include (a) disasters declared under a major disaster declaration; or (b) disasters declared under a state of emergency declaration under the Stafford Act.

Federal accidental loss is the loss of personal accidental loss or theft of personal use property caused by a federally declared disaster. Accidental loss must have occurred in the state receiving the federal accidental loss declaration. If you suffer a federal accidental loss, you are eligible to claim an accidental loss deduction. If you suffer an accidental loss or personal use property caused by a disaster that is not caused by a federally declared disaster, it is not a federal accidental loss, unless exceptional circumstances apply. You may not claim an accidental loss deduction. Theft in a transaction for profit may still be deductible. See below deductible loss deduction.

Disaster loss is loss attributable to a federally declared disaster and loss occurring in an area eligible for assistance under a presidential declaration. Disaster loss must occur within the county where the loss is eligible for public or personal assistance (or both). Disaster loss is not limited to property used by an individual for personal use, but can also be claimed against personal business or earned property or by corporations, S corporations, and partnerships.

"Eligible disaster losses include personal accidental deaths and personal theft of property attributable to: a major disaster declared by the President in 2016 under Section 401 of the Stafford Act; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Storm Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; California wildfires in January 2017 and 2018; California wildfires declared by the President under Section 401 of the Stafford Act that occurred in 2018 and lasted no later than December 21, 2019 and lasted no later than January 19, 2020 (except for relief for wildfires in California in January 2018); and a major disaster declared by the President whose year dates are between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025".

From the tax year 2018 to 2025, if you are an individual, the accidental loss of personal use of property is deductible only for losses caused by a disaster declared by the federal government ("Federal Accidental Loss"). Personal use of property does not include business property or earned property. If the event that caused you to suffer the loss of personal use of property occurred before January 1, 2018 ("Not caused by a disaster declared by the federal government") but the accidental loss of property did not occur until January 1, 2018 or after that date, the accidental loss is not deductible. See the following article "When to Report Benefits" for more information about when the accidental loss of property occurred.

Because personal accident losses claimed under this special procedure are not disasters declared by the federal government, deductions are only available to the extent that such losses do not exceed your personal accident benefits. If you suffered property damage from the installation of certain imported drywall in your home between 2001 and 2009, you can deduct the maintenance fees paid for damage caused by corrosive drywall to your home and household appliances under a special procedure. Under this procedure, the maintenance fees you pay are considered accident losses for the year of payment. For example, maintenance fees you pay in 2024 can be deducted on your 2024 tax return, and maintenance fees you pay in 2023 can be deducted on your 2023 tax return.

If you choose not to follow this special procedure, you are subject to all of the provisions applicable to deductible accidental loss and you must complete line 1 of Form 4684 in accordance with the 9th column. This means, for example, that you must establish that the property damage, destruction or loss was caused by an identifiable event as defined under the Accidental Loss Clause. In addition, you must have evidence that proves the following:

Enter the amount you paid for repairs to your home and appliances that were damaged by corrosive drywall. Enter only the amount you paid to restore the home to its pre-clamping condition. Do not enter the amount you paid to repair or add to your home that would increase the value of your home to more than the value before the damage. If you replace appliances instead of repairing them, enter the following lower values: current cost of replacing the original appliance; or the base price of the original appliance (usually its cost).

If the amount in line 8 is less than or equal to the amount in line 3, you cannot use this special procedure to claim the deduction for accidental loss. If you have an outstanding claim (or you intend to seek compensation), you may have an income deduction or additional deduction in the next tax year, depending on the amount of compensation actually received.

Individuals report loss of income-generating property on Schedule A (Form 1040) ∙ Corporate property and income-generating property combined with loss of corporate property; net loss on Form 4797; if you do not have to file Form 4797, simply enter the net loss on your tax return in the line from Form 4797 ∙ For individuals who file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, enter the net loss on Schedule 1 (Form 1040) in line 4 ∙ Next to that line, enter the income-generating property on Form 4684; partnerships and S corporations should refer to Form 4684 for a description of where such income and loss is reported.

If your business property or income property is lost, your business property loss is combined with the total income of the business property. net loss is reported on Form 4797. if you don't have to file Form 4797, just enter the net loss on your tax return. for individuals who file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, attached to Form 1 (Form 1040) Line 4. next to that line, enter Form 4684 (Form 4684). individuals deduct any loss of the property. partnerships and S corporations should see Form 4684, to find out where the profit and loss of the business is reported.

If the damaged or stolen property is depreciated property that has been held for more than one year, you must treat all or part of the gain as ordinary income for the extent of the depreciation allowed or admissible. You calculate the ordinary income portion of the gain on Form 4797, Part III. See Chapter 3 of Publication No. 544, for details on obtaining depreciation reimbursement.

If you suffer accidental loss or theft, you must reduce your property base by any insurance or other compensation you receive and by any tax-deductible loss. The result is your property base adjusted. If you make any of the above base adjustments, the amount you spend on repairs to restore your property to its pre-disaster condition can increase your base adjusted. No qualified disaster relief payments can increase your property base adjusted. See the adjusted base for more information on the base adjustment, which is contained in Issue 551.

If your accidental loss or theft deduction results in your deductions for that year exceeding your income for that year, you may have a net operating loss (NOL). Generally, you can use the NOL to reduce your tax in a later year.
If you have questions about your taxes, need help with your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, go to IRS.gov for resources that can help you immediately.

After you receive all of your salary and income statements (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment compensation statements (in mailed or digital format), or other government payment statements (Form 1099-G), and interest, dividend, and retirement statements from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you can choose from several options to prepare and file your tax returns. You can either prepare your own tax returns, check your eligibility for exempt returns, or hire a tax professional to prepare your tax returns.

You need an IRS Online Account (OLA) to complete the form that requires your signature. You can choose to submit the form online or download a copy for mailing. You will need your file scanned to support your submission. For more information, go to IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms.

Please go to IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. Browse the amount you owe and break it down by tax year. View payment plan details or apply for a new payment plan. Make payments or view a 5-year payment history and any outstanding or planned payments. View your tax records, including key data from your most recent tax return and tax receipts. View digital copies of notices selected by the IRS. Approve or reject authorization requests from tax professionals. View your file address or manage your communication preferences.

Through an online account, you can access information to help you with your tax season. You can get a receipt, view your most recently filed tax return, and get adjusted total receipts. Go to IRS.gov/Account to create or access your online account.
The tool allows your tax professional to submit an authorization request to access your individual taxpayer's IRS Online Account (OLA). For more information, please visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

The Direct File is a permanent option for those taxpayers in participating states who are relatively simple in preparing their tax returns and filing certain types of income and claiming certain deductions and deductions. Although Direct File is not used for filing state tax returns, if you reside in a participating state, FileDirect will guide you to the state-supported tool that can be used to fill out and file state tax returns for free. Refer to IRS.gov/DirectFile.gov for more information, updates and frequently asked questions.

The IRS does not contact taxpayers via email, SMS (including short links), telephone, or social media channels to request or verify personal or financial information. It also does not request or verify personal identification numbers (PINs) for credit cards, bank or other financial accounts, passwords, or similar information. Go to IRS.gov/IdentityTheft (IRS Identity Theft Center web page) to obtain information about taxpayers, tax professionals, and businesses related to identity theft and data security. You can find out what steps you should take if your SSN is lost or stolen or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft.

The IRS cannot issue refunds for tax return applications for low-income family benefits (EICs) or additional child tax credits (ACTCs) until mid-February. The rule applies to all refunds, not just the portions associated with these credit benefits.

IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax bill directly from your checking or savings account without charging you anything. Debit, credit, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment service provider, pay online or by phone. Electronic money transfer: Use tax form software or arrange for payment through a tax professional when filing federal taxes. Federal tax e-filing system: This is the best option for businesses. Registration is required.

You can use the IRS.gov/Payments to find out more about your options. Apply for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) so that you can pay in monthly installments if you can't pay your taxes in full today. Once you complete the online process, you'll receive an immediate notification of whether your agreement has been approved. Use the Advance Tax Eligibility Preview to see if you can pay your tax debt with less than the full amount you owe. For more information about the discounted plan, please visit IRS.gov/OIC.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). TAS helps taxpayers resolve issues with the IRS, makes administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or correct problems, and protects taxpayer rights. We work to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and to ensure that you are aware of and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Advocacy Act.

The Taxpayer Bill of Rights describes the ten basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. For more information about these rights, what they mean to you, and how they apply to specific IRS situations you may encounter, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate. IRS.gov/Taxpayer-Rights. The TAS is dedicated to protecting the rights of taxpayers and ensuring that the IRS enforces tax laws in a fair and just manner.

Although the tax return is always signed by the tax return preparer, you are ultimately responsible for providing the tax return preparer with all the information needed to accurately prepare the tax return and for the accuracy of each item reported on the tax return. Any person paid to file taxes for others should have a thorough understanding of tax issues. For more information on how to select a tax return preparer, visit the Tax Return Preparer Tips on IRS.gov.

The Social Security Administration (SSA) provides a quick, free, and secure W-2 filing option for CPAs, accountants, registered agents, and individuals processing Form W-2 (Wages and Taxes) and Form W-2c (Corrections to Wages and Taxes) online at SSA.gov/employer.

If you are a sole proprietor, partnership, or S corporation, you can access tax information from the IRS records and perform additional actions using your business tax account. For more information, visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount.

The IRS is committed to serving taxpayers with limited English proficiency (LEP) through the provision of OPI services. OPI services are a federally funded program available at Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TACs), most IRS offices, and at every VITA/TCE filing location. OPI services support more than 350 languages.

For the 2018-2025 tax year, if you are an individual, the loss of personal property resulting from an accident and theft is deductible only for losses caused by a federally declared disaster ("Federal Accident Loss"). If you have personal accident benefits, the rule exception for limiting the deduction of personal accident and theft losses to federal accident losses applies. In this case, you may deduct the loss of personal injury resulting from a disaster that was not declared by the federal government to be no more than your personal accident benefit.

If a senior executive or director of a company whose shares are available for purchase on the open investment market has committed financial fraud or other illegal misconduct and disclosed that such conduct has caused a decline in the market value of the shares, you may not deduct such decline as a loss for theft. However, if the shares are sold or exchanged, or the shares become completely worthless, you may not deduct the value of the shares as a capital loss on Schedule D (Form 1040) of the Exchange. For more information on the sale of shares, valueless shares and capital loss, see Chapter 4 of the Publication No. 550.
